questions.text: A 59-year-old male patient presented with complaint of right sided facial weakness and loss of sensation on right side of the face with left side of body. Examination reveals Horner’s syndrome, nystagmus, vertigo, ataxia, hoarseness and dysphagia. The patient is not able to balance himself. What is the most common cause of this presentation?

choices.text: Due to occlusion of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery
Due to occlusion of the basilar artery
Due to occlusion of left posterior inferior cerebellar artery
Due to occlusion of anterior inferior cerebellar artery

questions.solution:
Lateral medullary syndrome , also known as Wallenberg syndrome is due to occlusion of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery

Lateral medullary ischemia d/o ipsilateral vertebral artery (in most cases) or PICA(in few cases)

  • I/L Horner's+I/L sensory alternation of pain and temp on face(V nerve nucleus involvement)
  • I/L Cerebellar ataxia(involvement of inferior cerebellar peduncle)
  • C/L Alternation of pain and temp on body(Spinothalamic tract involvement)
  • I/L Loss of taste(involvement of Nucleus tractus solitarious)
  • Difficulty in speech and swallowing(involvement of Nucleus ambiguus)

questions.text: 32 year old patient presented to emergency department with history of stroke. Angiography was planned .The artery marked as 1 in the following image is a branch of which artery ?
questions.solution: The marked artery is the posterior communicating artery of the circle of willis which is a branch of internal carotid artery (NOT PCA)

questions.text: During protein translation the triplet code of mRNA is read by a ribosome and assisted elongation and translation factors until it reaches a stop codon labeled: UAA, UAG, or UGA. Then, when a stop codon is reached, a releasing factor binds, removing the peptide from the active ribosome and completing translation. What will happen if a mutation causes the recruitment of a releasing factor prior to the completion of a full peptide?
questions.solution: Nonsense Mutation: The codon containing the changed base become a termination codon. For example, if the Ser codon UCA is given a different second base, A, to become UAA, the new codon causes termination of translation at that point and the production of a shortened (truncated) protein.

questions.text: A healthy 68-year old man has a tidal volume (VT) of 0.45L and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. His arterial PCO2 is 41 mm Hg and the PCO2 in the expired air is 35 mm Hg. What is his VD/ VT ratio, where VD is the dead space?
questions.solution:
To solve this we need to use the Bohr’s equation, which is as follows:-

PECO2 X VT = PACO2 X (VT – VD)

Rearranging the above gives

VD/ VT = (PACO2 – PECO2)/ PACO2 [mnemonic “paco minus peco divided by paco”] Because carbon dioxide is a highly diffusible gas,alveolarPCO2 is assumed to beequaltoarterialPCO2. Also, in the steady state, carbon dioxide excreted by the lungsequalsthat produced from metabolism.

VD/ VT = (41 -35)/ 41 = 6/41 = 0.146 or 15%

In a normal individual this should be less than 33%- 40%

questions.text: An obese young woman accidentally ingests a banned drug and develops a high-grade fever. It was once known to be used for weight reduction. The drug is known to affect ATP formation in the Electron Transport Chain. What could be that drug?
questions.solution:
Option C: 2, 4 dinitrophenol

  • The drug 2,4 dinitrophenol is an ionophore.
  • Ionophore allows proton to pass through & dissipates the electrochemical gradient generated by proton pumps.
  • Because it is a chemical ionophore, 2,4 DNP inhibits the last stage of the energy conversion process that is Uncouples the oxidation from phosphorylation. i.e. Oxidation continues without phosphorylation.
  • Because of this change potential energy of protons is lost in the form of heat rather than being converted to ATP which in turn results in increase in body temperature (hyperthermia) seen in this patient.

Option A: Barbiturate

  • Barbiturates such as amobarbital inhibit the electron transport from Complex I to Coenzyme Q.
  • So, they inhibit both oxidation and phosphorylation.
  • Barbiturate poisoning leads to hypothermia, not fever

Option B: Malonate

  • Malonate does not decouple oxidative phosphorylation.
  • It inhibits Electron Transport Chain Complex II.
  • It is an inhibitor of the TCA cycle (a competitive inhibitor of enzyme succinate dehydrogenase).

Option D: Rotenone

  • It does not decouple oxidative phosphorylation but inhibits it by inhibiting complex I.
  • Rotenone is produced naturally in the stem and seeds of certain plants.
  • It is a fish poison and is used for catching fish. It is not an over-the-counter drug.

questions.text: A previously well 18-year-old woman is admitted to the ICU because of altered mental status. She does not respond to instructions and her arms are postured in a flexor position. Laboratory data reveal a serum sodium concentration of 125 mmol/L. Her friends indicate that the patient had taken ecstasy at a party the night before and because she was extremely thirsty the next morning, she had consumed a lot of water in a short period of time. Assuming that the reduction in osmolarity is entirely due to water consumption, that her initial weight was 60 kg and that her initial osmolarity was 300 mOsm/L, which of the following is approximately the quantity of water she would have drunk to produce the observed hyponatremia?
questions.solution:
After ingesting water, it is absorbed from the intestine, enters the plasma, and rapidly achieves osmotic equilibrium with the interstitial and intra-cellular compartments. Assuming that she had a normal osmolarity of 300 mOsm/L initially, at her initial body weight of 60 kg, with 60% of body weight being water, her initial volume was 36 L. A sodium concentration of 125 mM is equivalent to an osmolarity of 250 mOsm/L. Assuming that her normal osmolarity of 300 mOsm was reduced to 250 mOsm by the ingestion of water, she drank approximately 7 L.

Osmolarity = mOsm/volume 

300 mOsm/L = 60 kg X 60% X 300/initial volume 

Initial volume = 10,800 mOsm/300 mOsm/L = 36 L

250 mOsm/L = 60 kg X 60%  X 300/new volume 

New volume = 10,800 mOsm/250 mOsm/L ≅ 43 L

Volume consumed = new volume - initial volume 

                                           = 43 L-36 L= 7 L 

The amount of water ingested by the patient was not likely this high because she probably lost significant amount of salt as sweat while under the influence of ecstasy. Her signs and symptoms are due to the brain swelling caused by hypotonicity.

questions.text: A 45 year old male is brought to emergency department following a RTA. He is having maxillofacial injury. Surgical repair is performed and condition is stabilised. After repair patient develops difficulty chewing food. O/E when patient is instructed to open his mouth, jaw deviates to the right side. The nerve that has been injured in this patient exist through which of the following foramina?
questions.solution:
foramina Structures passing
Foramen ovale
  • Mandibular nerve
  • Accessory meningeal artery
  • Lesser petrosal nerve
  • Emissary vein
Foramen spinosum
  • Middle meningeal artery and vein
  • Emissary vein
  • Nervus spinosum
Foramen lacerum
  • Greater petrosal nerve
Foramen rotundum
  • Maxillary nerve
Optic canal
  • Optic nerve and ophthalmic artery (associated with sympthatic fibres)
Stylomastoid foramen
  • Facial nerve
  • Posterior auricular artery
Petrotympanic fissure
  • Chorda tympani nerve
Internal acoustic meastus
  • Facial nerve
  • Nervus intermedius
  • Labyrinthine vessels
  • 8th nerve
Jugular foramen
  • Anterior part inferior petrosal sinus
  • Intermediate part: glossopharyngeal n
  • Vagus nerve
  • Accessory n
  • Meningeal branch of accessory pharyngeal a
  • Posterior part; IJV

This patient has symptoms consistent with injury to the third division of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve (CN] V3, mandibular nerve), which provides sensory innervation to the face and motor innervation to the muscles of mastication. These include the 3 muscles that elevate the jaw (masseter medial pterygoid, temporalis) and the single muscle that depress the jaw (lateral pterygoid) Unilateral injury to CN V3 will result in unopposed action of the contralateral pterygoid muscles which leads to deviation of the mandible toward the paralyzed side on opening the mouth. B/L paralysis would cause mandibular drop and lack of jaw movement. CN V3 exits the skull through the foramen ovale . The second division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V2, maxillary nerve exits the skull via the foramen rotundum (option C) The foramen spinosum contains the middle meningeal artery, middle meningeal vein and the meningeal (recurrent) branch of CN V3 which supplies the dura and contains sympathetic fibres (option D).

(option A).

The foramen lacerum contains vessels (meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery, emissary veins) and is otherwise occluded by fibrous issue and cartilage The Internal carotid artery passes along its superior surface but does not traverse it .

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male presents to the orthopedic surgeon after several years of complaining of elbow pain, which he claims may be due to playing tennis everyday. The orthopedic surgeon explains that arthoplasty may be useful in treating his condition. Upon performing surgery, the surgeon notes the following ?

Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this male?
questions.solution:
This patient is presented with arthritis due to alkaptonuria (also known as Ochronosis or Ochronotic arthritis) which is due to the deficiency in homogentisate oxidase.

Homogentisic acid accumulated→ get oxidised → gives rise to Black urine

→ Homogentisic acid gets polymerized in body forming ALKAPTON BODIES, which gets accumulated in:

  • Cartilages → Nose, ear pinna, intervertebral disc
  • Connective tissue has bluish black colour. Patient develops arthralgia & arthritis.

→ This condition is known as Ochronosis. Arthritis is also known as ochronotic arthritis

questions.text: Which of the following metabolites of cholesterol biosynthesis can accumulate in a patient on long-term statin therapy?
questions.solution:
Option C: HMG-CoA

  • Statins inhibit the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase, which reduces HMG-CoA to mevalonic acid. Therefore, HMG-CoA would be the metabolite that accumulates. It is important to note that this is the rate-limiting step in cholesterol biosynthesis.

Option A: Acetoacetyl-CoA

  • Option A is wrong as acetoacetyl-CoA would accumulate if HMG-CoA synthase were inhibited.

Option B: Mevalonate

  • Option B is wrong because statins do not inhibit phosphomevalonate kinase.

Option D: Squalene

  • Option D is wrong because statins do not inhibit squalene monooxygenase.

questions.text: A 4-months-old boy rapidly develops hypoglycemia after moderate activity. Blood examination reveals raised ketone bodies, lactic acid, and triglycerides. On examination, the liver & kidneys were enlarged. Histopathology of the liver shows deposits of normal structure glycogen in excess amounts. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Von Gierke disease

  • Most common glycogen storage disease presenting with hypoglycemia and normal glycogen structure is Von Gierke’s disease due to deficiency of enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase.
  • Clinical features:
    • Severe hypoglycemia
    • Ketosis
    • Massive hepatomegaly
    • Enlarged kidneys
    • Hypertriglyceridemia
    • Lactic acidosis
    • Hyperuricemia
    • Spleen not enlarged

Option B: Pompe’s disease

  • It is a lysosomal storage disorder but does not cause fasting hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis.
  • Deficiency of acid maltase causes Pompe's disease (a glycogen storage disease) with features such as hypotonia, cardiomegaly in muscles, hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia in liver.

Option C: McArdle disease

  • It is also known as type IV glycogen storage disease
  • In this disease, muscle glycogen is not mobilized properly in exercising muscle due to deficiency of enzyme muscle glycogen phosphorylase causing exercise intolerance and myoglobinuria.
  • So, increased lactic acid in blood and enlarged liver and kidney rule out the possibility of this disease in this patient.

Option D: Forbe’s disease

  • It is also known as Cori’s disease or limit dextrinosis due to accumulation of limit dextrin in liver under fasting condition as a result of Amylo-α (1→6)-glucosidase/debranching enzyme deficiency.
  • As glycogen deposits have normal structure and no limit dextrins are reported in the patient, so possibility of Forbe’s disease can be easily ruled out.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man has resting tremors, pill-rolling movements, rigidity, and bradykinesia. He also is experiencing a mild problem in daily life activities, which he owes to not being able to grasp things due to the tremor in his hand. Which of the following is most likely to be decreased in this man?

choices.text: Serotonin neurons in the raphe nuclei
GABA neurons in the caudate nucleus and putamen
Dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra

questions.solution:
Option C: Dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra

  • The substantia nigra is a part of your basal ganglia, forming connections with different parts of your brain. It produces dopamine, which controls movements and muscle tone
  • In Parkinson's disease, neurons of the substantia nigra progressively degenerate; as a result, the amount of DA available for neurotransmission in the corpus striatum is lowered

Option A: Serotonin neurons in the raphe nuclei

  • The raphe nuclei are the primary location in the brain to produce the neurotransmitter serotonin. The serotonin synthesized in the raphe nuclei is sent throughout the central nervous system.
  • Serotonin plays a key role in such body functions as mood, sleep, digestion, nausea, wound healing, bone health, blood clotting and sexual desire

Option B: GABA neurons in the caudate nucleus and putamen

  • Huntington's Disease (HD) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease caused by an expanded trinucleotide CAG repeat in the HTT gene.
  • The striatum, comprising the caudate nucleus (CAU) and putamen, is the primarily affected brain region in HD, where as many as 90% of neurons are lost in late-stage disease.
  • GABA is produced primarily by the caudate nucleus of the striatum

Option D: Acetylcholine neurons in the forebrain

  • Acetylcholine originates from two major places in the brain: 1) the basal forebrain and 2) the mesopontine tegmentum area.
  • Acetylcholine in the brain alters neuronal excitability, influences synaptic transmission, induces synaptic plasticity and coordinates the firing of groups of neurons.
  • It is decreased in dementia, especially Alzheimer's disease affecting older adults.

questions.text: A patient presents in the outpatient department complaining of tingling sensations in his hand. He also complains of feeling weak for the past few days. He is a vegetarian but is not eating a proper diet for quite some time. A thorough clinical examination shows that the patient also has a red and softened tongue and roughed lips. The physician suspected a vitamin deficiency and will order which of the following enzyme assay to detect this vitamin deficiency in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A:  Glutathione reductase

  • These are the typical presentation of riboflavin deficiency and marker enzyme for riboflavin deficiency is the glutathione reductase activity test, as this enzyme needs FAD as a prosthetic group for its activity.

Symptoms of B2 deficiency:

  • Corneal vascularization- earliest sign of deficiency.
  • Glossitis– inflammation of the tongue (magenta tongue- characteristic),
  • Cheilosis– redness and shiny appearance of lips.
  • Angular stomatitis- lesions at the mucocutaneous junction corners of the mouth, leading to painful fissures.
  • Seborrhoeic dermatitis– rough, scaly skin because of desquamation.

Option B: Transketolase

  • Transketolase activity is measured to asses thiamine deficiency as this enzyme require TPP as its cofactor.

Option C: Histidine load test

  • Histidine load test is used for folic acid deficiency as the metabolism of histidine requires this vitamin.

Option D: Pyruvate dehydrogenase

  • PDH complex requires thiamine in the form of TPP. However, the deficiency of vitamin B1 is assessed with transketolase activity which is more easier and accurate to measure.

questions.text: Arterial blood gas of a 5 year old child done at sea level gives the following results: pH 7.41, PaO2, 100 mmHg, and PaCO2, 40 mm Hg. The child is being ventilated with 80% oxygen. What is the (A- a) DO2. - ?
questions.solution:
• Using the alveolar air equation -

PAO2 = [FIO2 × (PB – PH2O)] – [PaCO2/R]

Data:

Fraction of O2 in the inspired air = 80%

Barometric pressure = 760 mm Hg (sea level)

Water vapor pressure = 47 mm Hg

Respiratory quotient = 0.8

Hence,

Alveolar PO2 = [(80/100) × (760 – 47)] – [40/0.8]

= 570.4 – 50

= 520.4 mm Hg

Arterial PO2 is given = 100 mm Hg

Hence, (A – a) DO2 = 520.4 – 100 = 420.4 mm Hg

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy developed acute pain in his abdomen while he was being prepared for surgery for his cleft lip. On history, he revealed that he had had several episodes like this before. On examination, xanthomas were observed with enlarged spleen and liver. Blood examination revealed milky plasma. Which lipoprotein is most likely increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Chylomicrons

  • Milky plasma in this patient means chylomicrons are increased.
  • Chylomicrons contain TGs. But TGs is a lipid, and chylomicron is lipoprotein (the question is asking about lipoprotein).
  • This is a case of type I Hyperlipoproteinemia, which is due to a defect in the lipoprotein lipase enzyme.
  • It's a common inherited disorder, and the body is simply unable to break lipids and fats, and large amounts pile up in the blood and make it viscous or thick milky plasma, which is characteristic of it; the patient's plasma will show the following features:

First test tube: Creamy layer on the top after centrifugation

Second test tube: Normal serum on the top after centrifugation

Option A: VLDL Remnant

  • These are major atherogenic lipoproteins in the postprandial plasma.
  • They are increased in case of broad beta disease which is due to apo E defect

Option C: Triglycerides

  • TG will be raised in this patient but question ask about lipoprotein.

Option D: Cholesterol

  • They are increased in case of Familial Hypercholesterolemia and broad beta disease.
  • Hypercholesterolemia can cause cholelithiasis

questions.text: While removing a fish bone stuck in the throat, the main trunk of internal laryngeal nerve was severed. The bone was stuck in the ?
questions.solution: On either side of the laryngeal orifice is a recess, termed the piriform sinus (also piriform recess, pyriform sinus, piriform fossa, or smuggler's fossa), which is bounded medially by the aryepiglottic fold, laterally by the thyroid cartilage and thyrohyoid membrane. The fossae are involved in speech. Deep to the mucous membrane of the piriform fossa lies the internal laryngeal nerve, a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. The internal laryngeal nerve supplies sensation to the area, and it may become damaged if the mucous membrane is inadvertently punctured.

questions.text: Patient presented to OPD with chronic back pain which limits day to day activity. Routine investigation was performed. The highlighted muscle in red is supplied by which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
The given highlighted muscle is latissimus dorsi

Nerve Muscle it supplies
1. Thoracodorsal Lattisimus dorsi
2. Dorsal scapular Levator scapulae an rhom bodies
3. Long thoracic Serratus anterior
4. Lower subscapular Subscapularis and teres major
5. Upper subscapular Subscapularis

questions.text:
Analyze the following graph and match the following:-
P- acute respiratory acidosis
q- chronic respiratory acidosis
r – acute respiratory alkalosis
s- chronic respiratory alkalosis
questions.solution:
Let’s revise the normal values:

pCO2 = 40 mm Hg

plasma HCO3 = 25 mmHg

Before analyzing the options, it is important to know that acute acid base disorders deviate the pH more towards the abnormal than the chronic acid base disorders.

Label-1 = pH = ↑ (slightly)

HCO3 = ↓

pCO2 = ↓

= chronic respiratory alkalosis

Label – 2 = pH = ↑ (Greatly)

HCO3 = ↓

pCO2 = ↓

= Acute Respiratory alkalosis

Label – 3 = pH = ↓ (Slightly)

HCO3 = ↑

pCO2 = ↑

= chronic respiratory acidosis

Label – 4 = pH = ↓ (greatly)

HCO3 = ↑

pCO2 = ↑

= acute respiratory acidosis

It is also noteworthy to know that the direction of HCO3 compensation is in same direction as change in PCO2.

questions.text: There are three groups of people, labelled 1, 2 and 3. All three groups are on a relatively low iodine diet. Percentages are plotted against time after an oral dose of radioactive iodine. 1, 2 and 3 represent:
questions.solution:
1. In euthyroid state – Upon I123 intake, first there is rise of iodine in plasma, slowly this is taken up by the thyroid and excess is spilled over in the urine. Eventually, urine and thyroid concentration reach a plateau phase.
  2. In hyperthyroidism (Graves’ disease), after plasma rises in I 123 concentration, thyroid rapidly takes up I 123. This forms the basis of uniformly enhanced thyroid tissue in Graves’ disease on Radioactive Iodine Scan.
  3. In hypothyroidism (Hashimoto disease), the thyroid uptake of I 123 is minimal and urine excretion is increased. Hence, on Radioactive Iodine scan, the gland shows minimal enhancement.

questions.text: In portal hypertension lower end of the oesophagus may show dilation of veins, Which of the following veins drains into the portal vein from the lower end of the oesophagus?
questions.solution:
• Some esophageal veins drain into left gastric vein – portain vein.
  • Some esophageal veins drain into hemiazygous vein – superior vena cava.

questions.text: A patient with diverticulosis of the colon presents for follow-up to his primary care physician with ongoing complaints of left lower quadrant pain and occasionally bloody stools. His physician begins workup with appropriating test by recalling that the sigmoid colon?

choices.text: Receives parasympathetic fibers from the vagus nerve
Receives its blood from the superior mesenteric artery
Has teniae coli and epiploic appendages

questions.solution: The sigmoid colon has teniae coliand epiploic appendages. The sigmoid colon receives blood from the inferior mesenteric artery, drains its venous blood through the portal tributaries, has its own mesentery (sigmoid mesocolon; therefore, is not a retroperitoneal organ), and receives parasympathetic preganglionic fibers from the pelvic splanchnic nerve.

questions.text: Increase in heart rate and cardiac output are observed in a 32-year old woman. Simultaneous arterial blood gas analysis shows a normal PaO2 and PaCO2. These changes are most likely an integrated response to which of the following?
questions.solution: Increased heart rate and cardiac output with normal PaO2 and PaCO2 are most consistent with an integrated cardio respiratory response to exercise. Heart rate and cardiac output increase to meet the increased tissue oxygen demands, and the increase in ventilation increases oxygen supply and eliminates the excess carbon dioxide produced.

questions.text: Two students Robert and Kamal were asked to demonstrate in dogs the role of sinus nerve in hypovolemic shock. Robert severed the sinus nerve when the mean blood pressure (MBP) 85 mm Hg and Kamal cut the sinus nerve when the mean blood pressure was 60 mm Hg. On cutting the sinus nerve:

choices.text: Robert recorded the increasing MBP but Kamal recorded a decrease in MBP
Robert recorded a decrease in MBP but Kamal recorded in increase in MBP
Both recorded an increase in B.P
Both recorded a decrease in MBP

questions.solution: Both recorded an increase in B.P Explanation- Robert- At 85 mmHg: during this time baroreceptors are still active (to a lesser degree) so still inhibit vasomotor center, so after cutting the sinus nerve, all inhibitory effect on VMC will be lost, BP will rise. Kamal - at 60 mmHg, baroreceptors are also active (Threshold for excitation of Baroreceptors is 50mm Hg). Section of sinus nerve will also cause Increase in B.P.

questions.text: A 57- year old man, known case of coronary artery disease (coronary artery bypass done 3 years ago) was admitted with cough, shortness of breath and chest discomfort. As a result of drug therapy his LV pressure-volume loop changes from the solid line to the dashed line as shown below. Which of the following is most likely to increase as a result of this change?
questions.solution: The change as a result of the patient’s therapy indicates increased myocardial contractility and increased stroke volume. This will also increase the ejection fraction.

questions.text: A protein made of alpha helices and beta pleated sheet structures is treated with an experimental compound. On analysis it was found that both the structures were lost after treatment. Which of the following might be affected by this experimental compound?

choices.text: The primary structure of the protein
Covalent peptide bonds between amino acids

questions.solution:
Alpha helices and beta pleated sheets are both examples of secondary structures. These structures are maintained by a large number of hydrogen bonds between their amino acid residues.

So if this compound has disrupted these secondary structures so it is definitely affecting the hydrogen bonding ability of these amino acid residues.

If the primary structure would have been affected the covalent peptide binds has to be broken which will lead to release of individual amino acid residues which was not seen in this experiment.

Ionic bonds do not a role in secondary structure of proteins.

questions.text: A patient presents in emergency ward after an accident. He got injured with a sharp instrument. It was found that the instrument passed through the superior orbital fissure and common tendinous ring. It would have most likely severed which of the structures?
questions.solution:
The superior orbital fissure Bounded by the greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid

  • Transmits the following structures
  • Through the annulus of Zinn (a common tendinous ring from which the recti muscles originate) Superior and inferior divisions of the oculomotor nerve
  1. Nasociliary nerve
  2. Abducens nerve
  3. Outside the annulus of Zinn
  4. Lacrimal Nerve
  5. Frontal Nerve
  6. Trochlear Nerve
  7. Recurrent meningeal branch of the ophthalmic artery

questions.text:
Given the mRNA sequence shown below, if translation were to start at the first base, what would the tRNA anticodon be for the last amino acid translated in the chain?
5'—GCACCGGCCUGACUAUAA—3'
questions.solution:
The correct tRNA sequence is 3' CGG 5'. You must know that UGA, UAA, UAG are stop codons in the mRNA sequence. The codon immediately before the stop codon is the last one translated.

mRNA is read 5' to 3', so the complementary tRNA sequence (anticodon) is 3' to 5'. Using these two rules, the first stop codon in the mRNA sequence above is 5' UGA 3'. The mRNA sequence immediately before that is 5' GCC 3'. Therefore the tRNA sequence should be 3' CGG 5' (See fig).

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient vomited and then aspirated some of the vomitus while under anesthesia. On bronchoscopic examination, partially digested food is observed blocking the origin of the right superior lobar bronchus. Which of the following groups of bronchopulmonary segments will be affected by this obstruction?
questions.solution:
• The superior lobar bronchus is one of the divisions of the right main bronchus.
  • This bronchus branches into apical, anterior, and posterior tertiary bronchi.

LOBE- Right upper lobe

SEGMENTS:

  • Apical segment
  • Anterior segment
  • Posterior segment

questions.text: Experimental gastric function monitoring in healthy subjects performed before, during and after a meal shows an initial rise, peak and then decline in gastric acid production. Which of the following helps most to down-regulate gastric secretion after a meal?
questions.solution:
There are three phases of gastric secretion- cephalic, gastric and intestinal. Thought, sight, smell and tasteof food triggers gastric secretion in the cephalic phase. This phase is mediated by vagus.

Gastric phase is triggered by distension of the stomach. This phase is mainly hormonal, gastrin being the hormone responsible for this phase.

The intestinal phase is initiated when protein- containing food enters into the duodenum, but this phase plays only a minor role in stimulating the gastric acid secretion. In fact intestinal influences are effective in down-regulating gastric acid secretion after a meal. The factors which help to down regulate gastric acid secretion are peptide YY (from ileum and colon), somatostatin (from delta cells in the small intestine) and prostaglandins.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child presents with complaints of aggressive behavior and developmental delay. On examination, light brown hair is seen, whereas both of his parents had black hair. A diagnosis is made after further investigations, and he has been advised to supplementation of large doses of tryptophan, leucine, and tyrosine in his diet. Which one of the following is the reason behind this treatment?
questions.solution:
Option C: To restore neurotransmitter synthesis

This patient with aggressive behavior, developmental delay, and light brown hair most likely have Classic phenylketonuria.

  • Classic phenylketonuria (PKU) is a family of diseases caused by 100 or more mutations in the gene that codes for Phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH), a key enzyme for the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine.
  • The inability of phenylalanine to get converted to tyrosine leads to unusually high levels of phenylalanine which are instead converted to phenyl lactate, phenylpyruvate, and phenylacetate.
  • This disease gets its name from high levels of phenyl ketones in the body.
  • These unusually high phenylalanine levels and its metabolites result in CNS symptoms, including mental retardation, developmental delays, failure to walk or talk, and seizures).
  • Patients with classic show features of hypopigmentation (fair hair, light skin, and blue eyes). It is due to the competitive inhibition of tyrosinase by unusually higher levels of phenylalanine, an essential enzyme for the first step in converting tyrosine to melanin.
  • In the normal metabolism of phenylalanine, tyrosine is a non-essential amino acid as it is endogenously produced. Nevertheless, in classic PKU, tyrosine becomes an essential amino acid.
  • Tyrosine is then metabolized to dopamine and norepinephrine – two critical neurotransmitters in the brain.
  • High phenylalanine concentrations decrease brain neurotransmitter concentrations by out-competing the absorption of tyrosine, tryptophan, and leucine.
  • Therefore, the standard dietary regimen in classic PKU consists of a diet low in phenylalanine and high in tyrosine and tryptophan to restore adequate levels of neurotransmitters in the brain and minimize the risk of mental retardation.

Option A: To inhibit PAH activity

  • Phenylalanine hydroxylase needs obligatory cofactor tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) for its regulation, and no other factors significantly affect the enzymatic activity.
  • Increased dietary intake of tyrosine, tryptophan, and leucine may affect the absorption of phenylalanine in the GI tract but does not affect the enzymatic activity of PAH.
  • Additionally, the activity of PAH is already compromised in PKU.

Option B: To activate PAH activity

  • As explained above, PAH's activity is regulated by coenzyme BH4 only, and no other factors affect this activity.
  • Additionally, the activity of PAH is already compromised in PKU.

Option D: To stimulate protein synthesis

  • Amino acids consumed more than the amounts needed for nitrogenous tissue constituents are not stored but are degraded.
  • Leucine is the only amino acid that can stimulate muscle protein synthesis at a very high dose, an effect enhanced in vivo by insulin secretion in response to the leucine dose.
  • The purpose of high doses of these amino acids aims to outcompete phenylalanine to restore neurotransmitters rather than stimulate protein synthesis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old HIV positive female gave birth to a 3.2 kg baby girl. She was not regular in taking her prescribed dose of anti-retroviral medications during pregnancy. Which of the following assays would a hospital use to detect the genetic material of HIV if the child had been infected?
questions.solution:
Out of all the techniques mentioned only Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) will detect the presence of genetic material.

All other method mentioned will detect protein (by antigen-antobody interactions) instead of genetic material (DNA/RNA)

Genetic material extracted from child blood can be used to amplify HIV specific genes using HIV specific primers in a PCR reaction. If there is amplification and band were seen on gel then the child can be said to have HIV infection.

questions.text: E. coli has the ability to regulate its enzymes to break down various sources of energy when available. It prevents waste by the use of the lac operon, which encodes a polycistronic transcript. At a low concentration of glucose and absence of lactose, which of the following occurs?

choices.text: Increased allolactose levels bind to the repressor
Increased cAMP levels result in binding to the catabolite activator protein
Decreased cAMP levels result in poor binding to the catabolite activator protein
Trascription of the lac Z, Y, and A genes increase

questions.solution: At a low concentration of glucose, cAMP levels rise resulting in cAMP binding to the catabolite activator protein (CAP). This enhances the activity of RNA polymerase, but since lactose is absent, the repressor is still bound to the lac operator.

questions.text:
A young man with history of seizure disorder is seen in the ER with complaints of confusion and stomach pain. His seizures are currently being treated with phenytoin. After talking with the patient you examine a urine sample

You suspect he has a deficit in which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
This patient with abdominal pain, reddish-brown urine (due to excretion of ALA and PBG in urine) and psychological disturbances likely has acute intermittent porphyria (AIP), caused by a defect in porphobilinogen deaminase.

Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase deficiency leads to Porphyria Cutanea Tarda (PCT) due to block later in the pathway causing photosensitivity.

The other two enzymes are related to carbohydrate metabolism and does not result in reddish brown urine color.

questions.text: 45-year-old male has a large intraabdominal mass in the midline just above the pubic symphysis. During surgery a cystic mass is found attached to the umbilicus and to the apex of the bladder. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The persistence of the epithelial lining of the urachus can give rise to a urachal cyst. This swelling is found in the midline in the umbilical region.

  • Hydrocele is fluid accumulation between the visceral and parietal layers of the tunica vaginalis of the testis.
  • A Meckel diverticulum is located in the ileum of the small intestine. When it becomes inflamed, it can cause symptoms of appendicitis. A diverticulum can form a cyst (Meckel cyst).

questions.text: The ribosome is an essential organelle that plays an important role in the synthesis of new proteins. The location of the ribosome within the cell can vary and provides a clue to the function of the particular cell. What ribosome location is essential for protein-secreting cells?
questions.solution:
Cells that secrete a large quantity of protein into the extracellular space are equipped with a large quantity of RER.

The ribosomes attached to the RER synthesize proteins directly into the inner portion of RER, so that these amino acids are never exposed to the cytosol.

The RER then secretes vesicles that transport nascent amino acids and proteins to the golgi apparatus, again without the protein being exposed to the cytosol.

The golgi then secretes the proteins in vesicles, which fuse with the cellular membrane, ensuring that cellular topology is maintained through the synthesis and secretion of proteins.

questions.text: Which of the following statements concerning the nerve supply to the urinary bladder is not correct?

choices.text: The sympathetic postganglionic fibre originate in the first and second lumbar ganglia
The parasympathetic preganglionic fibres synaple with postganglionic neurons in the inferior hypogastric, plexuses
The afferent sensory fibres arising in the bladder reach the spinal cord via the pelvic splanchnic nerves and also travel with the sympathetic nerves
The parasympathetic preganglionic fibres inhibit detrusor

questions.solution:
• Parasympathetic fibers – nervi erigentes – S2-4 – MOTOR TO detrusor.
  • Sympathetic fibers – Inhibitory to detrusor.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman underwent a complete mastectomy, including removing several axillary lymph nodes. The lymph nodes were all negative. However, the patient is found to have winging of the scapula when her flexed arm is pressed against a fixed object. This indicates injury to which of the following nerves?
questions.solution: The serratus anterior muscle (protractor and stabilizer of the scapula) is innervated by the long thoracic nerve (of Bell), which arises from roots C5 to C7 of the brachial plexus. During modified radical mastectomy, this nerve is usually spared to maintain shoulder function. However, its location places it in jeopardy during the lymphatic resection. The suprascapular nerves are sensory branches of the cervical plexus. The axillary nerve, deep in the brachial portion of the axilla, innervates the deltoid muscle. The thoracodorsal nerve which arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus, innervates the latissimus dorsi. Thel ower subscapular nerve innervates the teres major muscle and a portion of the subscapularis muscle.

questions.text: A 38-year-old farmer is brought to the emergency department in an altered state of consciousness. The patient had profuse sweating and lacrimation. Diarrhoea and urinary incontinence  were apparent in this patient. On examination of the patient, the pupils were constricted, and the blood pressure of the patient was 80/60 mmHg. The doctor administered atropine to the patient, which reversed the symptoms of the patient except for one. The treatment involved in this case failed to reverse which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option C: Muscle paralysis

  • This is a case of organophosphate poisoning in which the patient presents to the emergency department in an altered state of consciousness. The patient had profuse sweating and lacrimation.
  • Diarrhoea and urination were apparent in this patient. On examination of the patient, the pupils were constricted, and the blood pressure of the patient was 80/60 mmHg.
  • All these symptoms and findings suggest organophosphate poisoning.
  • This poisoning can be caused by insecticides.
  • The mechanism of this poisoning is the inhibition of acetylcholinesterase.
  • The doctor administered atropine to this patient, which reversed most of the symptoms, but it could not reverse muscle paralysis.
  • It is because atropine blocks muscarine receptors which will result in the reverse of sweating, lacrimation, diarrhoea and urination.
  • Muscle paralysis is caused due to nicotinic receptors.

Option A: Hypotension

  • The hypotension will be reversed by atropine.
  • Because it will block parasympathetic action, which will result in normalising the blood pressure of the patient.

Option B: Central excitation

  • Atropine will treat central excitation.
  • It can penetrate the blood-brain barrier and reverse the muscarinic action in the CNS.

Option D: Bronchoconstriction

  • It can also reverse bronchoconstriction caused due to stimulation of muscarinic receptors.

questions.text: A 10 year old boy present with a palpable mass per abdomen. On imaging paraaortic lymph nodes were found to be enlarged. A biopsy from the lymph nodes showed a starry sky appearance. What is the likely underlying abnormality ?
questions.solution: All forms of Burkitt lymphoma are highly associated with translocations of the MYC gene on chromosome 8 that lead to increased MYC protein levels. MYC is a master transcriptional regulator that increases the expression of genes that are required for aerobic glycolysis, the so-called Warburg effect. The tumor exhibits a high mitotic index and contains numerous apoptotic cells, the nuclear remnants of which are phagocytosed by interspersed benign macrophages. These phagocytes have abundant clear cytoplasm, creating a characteristic “starry sky” pattern. When the bone marrow is involved, aspirates reveal tumor cells with slightly clumped nuclear chromatin, two to five distinct nucleoli, and royal blue cytoplasm containing clear cytoplasmic vacuoles.

questions.text: While Doing a post-mortem you noticed a completely destroyed tattoo marking on the back of a female victim .If the Tattoo marks are destroyed, their presence can be inferred from presence of pigment in ?
questions.solution: Latent tattoos are invisible tattoo marks. In a living person these invisible tattoo marks can be made visible by ultraviolet rays. In a dead body, previous application of tattoo mark can be determined by regional lymph node biopsy where there will be presence of dye.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child is evaluated for recurrent skin and respiratory infections. He has light skin and silvery hair. Horizontal nystagmus is present on eye examination. Peripheral blood smear shows giant cytoplasmic granules in neutrophils and monocytes. This boy is most likely suffers from which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
• Primary immunodeficiency from problems with phagocytosis
  • Autosomal recessive, defect in lysosomal trafficking regulator gene (LYST).
  • Microtubule dysfunction with failure of phagolysosome formation
  • Defective melanisation of melanosomes
  • Partial albinism, Pyogenic infections and peripheral neuropathy

questions.text: A healthy 45-year-old male undergoes an elective hernia repair with meshplasty under spinal anaesthesia. Postoperatively, he develop difficulty in voiding. Bladder catheterization shows a post-void residual of 500cc of urine. As an operating surgeon which among the following drugs would you prescribe this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has postoperative urinary retention because of decreased contractility of the bladder detrusor muscle and incomplete emptying. Contraction of the detrusor muscle is stimulated by muscarinic cholinergic agonists like Bethanechol.

  • (option A) Finasteride is prescribed for patients with bladder outlet obstruction secondary to prostatic hypertrophy
  • (option B) Phenylephrine is an alpha agonist which promotes, rather than alleviates urinary retention.
  • (option D) Oxybutynin is an antimuscarinic agent commonly used for urge incontinence .

questions.text: The forensic team has begun its investigations at the crime scene. A well-known politician was found dead from a gunshot wound in his bedroom. The relatives and the political friend circle are alleging that he was murdered. On initial investigation, the victim was found with the shotgun lying next to his right hand and there was also a clear handwritten suicide note by the side of the bed. Which among the following  would help the team to confirm it to be suicidal in nature?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Gunshot residues in the hand

 

Explanation:

 

To differentiate between suicide and homicide, forensic evidence must demonstrate that the deceased fired the weapon. The most reliable indicator of this is the presence of gunshot residue (GSR) on the hand, especially on the dorsum (back) of the dominant hand and web space between thumb and index finger.

The presence of GSR particles (lead, barium, antimony) on the hand provides objective chemical evidence that the person discharged the firearm, strongly supporting a suicidal act.

Gunshot Residue testing (e.g., using SEM or Griess test) is the most reliable indicator that the victim personally fired the gun, helping to confirm suicide over homicide.

 

Forensic Significance of GSR:

Factor Suicide Homicide
GSR on deceased's hand Common Usually absent
Gun in hand May be present Can be staged
Suicide note Suggestive, not definitive May be forged
Fingerprints on weapon Helpful, but inconclusive Can be absent even in suicide

 

Fingerprint on the gun (Option A): While helpful, fingerprints can be planted or wiped, and the presence alone doesn’t confirm the person fired the weapon.

Blood on the gun (Option B): Blood may be present due to proximity to the wound, not necessarily from the act of firing.

Gun in hand (Option C): "Gun in hand" can be staged post-mortem. It is not a definitive sign of suicide.

questions.text: Most important epidemiological tool used for assessing disability in children is:

choices.text: Wing’s Handicaps, Behavior and Skills (HBS) Schedule

questions.solution:
• Wing’s Handicaps, Behavior and Skills (HBS) Schedule: One of the most important epidemiological tool used for assessing abilities and disabilities in children

- Wing’s HBS is not useful for those who are not retarded

MENTAL HEALTH RATING SCALES IN CHILDREN:

  • Adaptive behavior Scale (AAMR ABS): To evaluate functional and behavioral disorder in children and adolescents with mental retardation, autism and other developmental disabilities
  • Child Behaviour Checklist (CBCL) Scale: To evaluate pathological behaviours and social competence in children aged 1 ½ to 18 years.
  • Children’s Depression Inventory (CDI) Scale: To evaluate depression in children and adolescents
  • Children’s Depression Rating Scale (CDRS): To evaluate severity of depression in children
  • Comprehensive Behaviour Rating Scale for Children (CBRS (C): To assess psychopathology and behavioural problems in children and adolescents
  • Diagnostic Interview Schedule for Children (DIS (C): To diagnose mental disorders in children and adolescents
  • Revised Children’s Manifest Anxiety Scale (RCMAS): To evaluate anxiety in children
  • Reynolds Adolescent Depression Scale (RADS): To screen for and measure depression in adolescents

questions.solution:
Extrapyramidal side effects of anti-psychotics are:

choices.text: Repeat the dose once vomiting has controlled.
Start the child on IV fluids.

questions.solution:
A child vomits immediately after taking rota virus vaccine : Repeat the dose once vomiting has controlled

  • Routine rotavirus vaccination recommended for all infants begins at 6 weeks of age [1 dose], followed by 1 dose each in 10th & 14 weeks of age.
  • Rotavirus vaccine can be given up till 1 year age in National immunization

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the office due to gradually progressive pain, stiffness, and swelling of her hand joints for the past months with morning stiffness and as well as generalized fatigue. The patient has tried pain medications, such as acetaminophen and ibuprofen with only minimal relief of her symptoms .She has no other medical problems. Family history is significant for diabetes mellitus .Which of the following drugs would provide the most rapid relief of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has swelling, pain, and morning stiffness in multiple joints for >6 weeks, points toward the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The treatment is disease-modifying anti rheumatic drugs (DMARDs methotrexate ( first-line), sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine, minocycline, and tumor necrosis factor-alpha inhibitors.

However, the response to DMARD therapy takes weeks (Option B, C) Therefore, short-term treatment with systemic and intraarticular glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone) or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), can provide rapid, temporary relief of symptoms in patients starting on DMARDs.

Colchicine is used in the management of both acute and chronic gout and also it is not effective in RA.

questions.text: If a victim’s gunshot entry and exit wound are not properly distinguishable during post-mortem due to corrective surgery, it is known as:
questions.solution:
Kennedy phenomenon:

1)    Kennedy phenomenon is surgical intervention of firearm wound, hence rendering the wound difficult to interpret during autopsy as happened in Kennedy’s case.

2)    Surgical intervention may make interpretation of gunshot wounds difficult as a result of obliteration or alteration of wounds.

3)    For example, chest tube insertion at the site of entry wound or craniotomy in case of firearm injury to the head may alter wound track.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman arrives at the emergency room complaining of fatigue and dark-colored urine. While obtaining the history of her present illness, you learn that she has been recovering from a recent bout of pneumonia, for which she had been treated appropriately by her primary care physician with a course of antibiotics. Physical examination reveals an enlarged spleen and slight scleral icterus. You obtain a blood sample and see the following. What is your diagnosis?

choices.text: Autoimmune haemolytic anemia- cold antibody type
Autoimmune haemolytic anemia- warm antibody type

questions.solution:
• Cold agglutinin type of immunohemolytic anemia is caused by IgM antibodies that bind red cells avidly at low temperatures (0°C to 4°C).
  • Cold agglutinin antibodies sometimes appear transiently following certain infections, such as with Mycoplasma pneumoniae, EpsteinBarr virus, cytomegalovirus, influenza virus, and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).
  • In these settings the disorder is self-limited and the antibodies rarely induce clinically important hemolysis.
  • Chronic cold agglutinin immunohemolytic anemia occurs in association with certain B-cell neoplasms or as an idiopathic condition .
  • Clinical symptoms result from binding of IgM to red cells in vascular beds where the temperature may fall below 30°C, such as in exposed fingers, toes, and ears.
  • IgM binding agglutinates red cells and fixes complement rapidly.

As the blood recirculates and warms, IgM is released, usually before complement-mediated hemolysis can occur

questions.text: The following immunofluorescence picture is most likely seen in which of the following blistering disorders?
questions.solution:
• Bullous pemphigoid is caused by autoantibodies that bind to proteins that are required for adherence of basal keratinocytes to the basement membrane
  • Most antibody deposition occurs in a continuous linear pattern at the dermo epidermal junction, which contains specialized structures called hemidesmosomes that link basal keratinocytes to the underlying basement membrane
  • The so-called bullous pemphigoid antigens (BPAGs) are components of hemidesmosomes.
  • Antibodies against one such component called BPAG2 are proven to cause blistering.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with a fever and cough for the last three days. The cough is productive, with small amounts of clear sputum. On examination, he is febrile with inflamed and enlarged tonsils. The physician sent him for a sputum culture, and the microbiologist used blood agar for culturing it. What type of culture media is blood agar?
questions.solution:
Correct answer

Option A: Enriched media

  • Blood agar is an example of  Enriched media.

Enriched Media

  • The media that contains extra nutrients, in addition to the basal medium, which allows the growth of a wide variety of microorganisms, including fastidious organisms, is called enriched media. They are usually solid media. These extra nutrients include blood, serum, and egg yolk.

Examples:

  • Blood agar: 5-10% sheep blood agar
  • Chocolate agar: nutrient agar is melted & cooled at 75oC in a water bath + 5-10% sterile defibrinated sheep blood is added & mixed.
  • BHI agar [brain heart infusion agar]
  • Loeffler’s serum slope [used for Corynebacterium diphtheriae]

  Other Options          

Option B: Indicator media

Indicator media:

  • It contains certain dyes or metabolic substrates in the medium composition. When the bacteria utilize or react with these components, it forms different colours in colonies of different microbial species. It allows the growth of more than one microorganism at a time. Still, the bacterial colonies can be differentiated based on their colours, such as neutral red, phenol red, and methylene blue.

Examples:

1. Wilson-Blair's agar → Salmonella typhi produces black colonies.

2. Mac-Conkey’s agar: The lactose fermenting bacteria forms pink-red colonies, while lactose non-fermenters form pale or colourless colonies. It is also selective & differential media)

3. CLED media [cysteine lactose electrocyte deficient] → both indicator & differential media.

Option C: Enrichment media

Enrichment media:

  • The highly selective media which allows the growth of only a particular type of organism by inhibiting the growth of unwanted, commensal, and contaminating microorganisms are called enrichment media. It is always a liquid culture media.

Examples:

  • Selenite F broth: for Salmonella, Shigella
  •  Tetrathionate broth: for Salmonella
  • Alkaline peptone water- for Vibrio

Option D: Selective media

Selective culture media:

  •  Selective media only allow certain organisms to grow and inhibit the growth of all other organisms. For Example, if organisms that can utilize a given sugar are provided with that particular as the only carbon source in the medium sugar, they can be easily screened. Similarly, selective inhibition of some types of microorganisms can be done by adding dyes, antibiotics, salts, or specific inhibitors which affect the metabolism or enzyme systems of the organisms.

Examples:

  • LJ (Lowenstein Jensen) media: Mycobacterium tuberculosis → malachite green [selective agent]
  • Deoxycholate citrate: It is used for Salmonella and Shigella.
  • Bile salt agar: for Vibrio cholerae
  • TCBS agar for Vibrio cholerae (thiosulphate citrate bile salt sucrose) → green colour media, changes to yellow when Vibrio grows
  •  LSS (Loeffler serum slope): Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.text: The following histopathology appearance of a lymph node involved with lymphoma is can be seen in all of the listed lymphomas except ?
questions.solution: The histopathology finding is that of starry sky appearance which is an indication of a high grade lymphoma and CLL is a low grade lymphoma

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman develops right upper limb lymphedema after mastectomy as a result of axillary lymph node dissection. 10 years later, she presents with multiple confluent, haemorrhagic, necrotic, and elevated purple-black papules over the right upper limb. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The most likely diagnosis in this setting is lymphangiosarcoma. Angiosarcoma can arise in the setting of lymphedema, classically in the ipsilateral upper extremity, several years after radical mastectomy with lymph node resection for breast cancer known as Stewart-Treves.

questions.text: Several children at a summer camp were hospitalized with symptoms thought to be due to ingestion of food containing botulinum toxin. The effects of botulinum toxin are likely to include:
questions.solution: Botulinum toxin interferes with the release of ACh and thus acts as a parasympatholytic agent. Bronchospasm and diarrhoea are the symptoms of muscarinic stimulation whereas muscle spasms may be seen on nicotinic stimulation. Cholinergic drugs cause cyclospasm whereas anticholinergics result in cycloplegia.

questions.text: A new diagnostic test for TB has a sensitivity of 90% & specificity of 95%. If applied to a population of 1 lakh patients in which the prevalence of TB is 1%, how many FN results would you expect?
questions.solution:
A false negative is a diseased subject misclassified as healthy. In this problem, the prevalence is 1% so there are 1,000 patients with TB. Of these, 90% will be correctly classified and 10% will be misclassified. Therefore, the number of false negatives is 100.

Gold standard
Screening test TP (900) FP
FN (100) TN
1000 99000 100000

Sensitivity = TP/TP+FN

90/100 = TP/1000

TP = 900

THEREFORE FN = 100

questions.text: With reference to school health service, which of the following statement is not true?

choices.text: There should be one urinal for 60 students and one latrine for 100 students.
Per capita space for students in a classroom should not be less than 10 sq. ft.
The maximum recommended no. of students in a school class room is 40

questions.solution:
School Environment

Site : The site should be on suitable high land, and not subject to inundation or dampness and can be properly drained. The School Health Committee (1961) had recommended that 10 acres of land be provided for higher elementary schools and 5 acres for primary schools with an additional one acre of land per 100 students. In congested areas, the nearest public park or playground should be made available to the students.

Structure : Nursery and secondary schools, as far as possible, be single storied. Exterior walls should have a minimum thickness of 10 inches and should be heat resistant.

Classroom :No classroom should accommodate more than 40 students. Per capita space for students in a classroom should not be less than 10 sq. ft.

Furniture : Furniture should suit the age group of students. It is desirable to provide single desks and chairs.

Desks should be of "minus" type. Chairs should be provided with proper back-rests, with facilities for desk-work.

Doors and windows: The windows should be broad with the bottom sill, at a height of 2'-6" from the floor level; combined door and window area should be at least 25 per cent of the floor space; windows should be placed on different walls for cross-ventilation; the ventilators should not be less than 2 per cent of the floor area.

Colour : Inside colour of the classroom should be white and should be periodically white-washed.

Lighting : Classrooms should have sufficient natural light, preferably from the left,and should not be from the front.

Water supply: There should be an independent source of safe and potable water supply, which should be continuous, and distributed from the taps.

Eating facilities : Vendors other than those approved by the school authorities should not be allowed inside school premises; there should be a separate room provided for mid-day meals

Lavatory : Privies and urinals should be provided - one urinal for 60 students and one latrine for 100 students. Arrangements should be separately made for boys and girls.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to OPD by her parents with complaint of recurrent bacterial infections. Her mother gives history of delayed umbilical cord detachment at after the birth of the patient. She is diagnosed with leukocyte adhesion defect. Mark the correct pair of given molecule with their role.
questions.solution:
LFA-1 (integrin)- Tight adhesion.

LAD (leukocyte adhesion defect) SYNDROME:

  • absence of CD 18.
  • Problem in common β chains of integrins.

Symptoms:

  • leads to recurrent infection.
  • failure to produce pus.
  • inflammation around umbilicus but no pus (omphalitis).

Intravascular cellular changes:

  • Margination
  • Rolling: Interaction between Sialyl Lewis X on WBC surface & selectin→ responsible for loose adhesion.
  • ICAM-1is a cell surface receptor that mediates the interaction between keratinocytes and leukocytes.
  • Ahesion: Interaction between Integrin on WBC surface & ICAM/ VCAM→ responsible for tight adhesion.
  • Integrin- made of subunits known as CD 11a/ LFA.
  • Transmigration/ Diapedesis: Occurs due to CD 31/ PECAM and Collagenase secreted by WBC.

questions.text: A 17 Year old patient develops intussusception for which he was operated and a segment of intestine showing multiple polyps was resected . Microscopy showed the following pathology . What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
The given histology shows a large polyp with an arborizing network of connective tissue is seen with well developed smooth muscle and surrounding normal abundant glands lined by normal intestinal epithelium rich in goblet cells. This is seen in Peutz Jegher’s polyp which is a type of hamartomatous polyp.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

  • Autosomal dominant disorder
  • Most com­mon in small intestine → Jejunum
  • Germ line loss of function mutations in LKB1/STK11 gene are present
  • May occur in stomach, colon & with much lower frequency in bladder and lungs
  • Multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps + Mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation
  • Gross- Polyps are large & pedunculated with lobulated contour
  • Histologic findings :characterized by proliferation of the muscularis mucosae to form branching configurations covered by hypertrophic,

questions.text: A category 1 TB patient on treatment is sputum positive after 2 months of intensive phase. What is the next line of management ?
questions.solution:
A category 1 TB patient on treatment is sputum positive after 2 months of intensive phase : Start Continuation phase and finish treatment.

  • No need to extend 1 month of intensive phase

DOTS therapy under RNTCP [Revised National TB Control Programme] include:

- Category-1 - New sputum smear +ve ; New sputum smear -ve.

- Category-2 - Re-treatment case. [i.e recurrent TB cases ;Treatment after failure/ loss to follow?up]

- Both categories have same treatment regimen. [ New 2019 - 20 guideline]

- Regimen → 2 [ HRZE ] [Initiation phase] + 4 [HRE] [continuation phase] = Total 6 month duration.

  • H- Isoniazid
  • R – Rifampicin
  • Z – Pyrazinamide
  • E – Ethambutol

questions.text: A 58 year old male patient who previously was healthy develops bacterial meningitis. Assuming no specific contraindications, which of the following is the empirical treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Antibiotics Used in Empirical Therapy of Bacterial Meningitis and Focal Central Nervous System Infections:

INDICATION ANTINBIOTIC
Preterm infants to infants <1 month Ampicillin +cefotaxime
Infants 1-3 months Ampicillin +cefotaxime or ceftriaxone
Immunocompetent children >3 months and adults <55 Cefotaxime, ceftriaxone , or cefepime + vancomycin
Adults >55 andAdults of any age with alcoholism or other debilitating illnesses Ampicillin+ Cefotaxime, cefotaximeor cefepime+ vancomycin
Hospital-acquired meningitis, posttraumatic or postneurosurgery meningitis, neutropenic patients, or patients with impaired cell-mediated immunity Ampicillin+ceftazidime or meropenem+ vancomycin

questions.text: To determine if infection with Helicobacter pylori was associated with gastric cancer, investigators used a cohort of 128 992 people that had been established in the mid-1960s. By 1991, 186 people in the original cohort had developed gastric cancer. The investigators then did a study by selecting the 186 people with gastric cancer as cases and another 186 cancer-free individuals from the same cohort as controls. H. pylori infection status was determined retrospectively from serum samples that had been stored since the 1960s. 84% of people with gastric cancer and only 61% of the controls – had been infected previously with H. pylori, suggesting a positive association between H. pylori infection and gastric cancer risk. Which of the following is false regarding this study ?

choices.text: It is mainly a retrospective study
Follow up of the selected cohort is done

questions.solution:
Nested case control study :

  • It is mainly a prospective study
  • No recall bias
  • Follow up of the selected cohort is done
  • Temporal association is seen.

questions.text: A premature neonate suffers pneumonia and sepsis. Sputum culture on blood agar plate yields pinpointed β-hemolytic colonies. Which of the following is a simple biochemical test to determine whether the organism is S. agalactiae or L. monocytogenes ?
questions.solution:
Streptococcus agalactiae (group B streptococci) is the leading cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis. All streptococci (including S. agalactiae) are catalase-negative, whereas staphylococci are catalase positive. Listeria monocytogenes is also catalase-positive.

Other options:

Bacitracin test: for Streptococcus pyogenes

Coagulase test: For Staph aureus

Polymerase chain reaction: It is not a biochemical test.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man complains of a urethral discharge. You perform a Gram stain on a specimen of the discharge and see neutrophils but no bacteria. Of the organisms listed, the one MOST likely to cause the discharge is:
questions.solution:
• C. trachomatis exists in more than 15 immunotypes (A–L).
  • Types A, B, and C cause trachoma, a chronic conjunctivitis endemic in Africa and Asia.
  • Trachomamay recur over many years and may lead to blindness but causes no systemic illness.
  • Types D–K cause genital tract infections, which are occasionally transmitted to the eyes or the respiratory tract. In men, it is a common cause of nongonococcal urethritis (often abbreviated NGU), which is characterized by a urethral discharge. This infection may progress to epididymitis, prostatitis, or proctitis.
  • In women, cervicitis develops and may progress to salpingitis and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Repeated episodes of salpingitis or PID can result in infertility or ectopic pregnancy.
  • Chlamydiae form cytoplasmic inclusions, which can be seen with special stains(e.g., Giemsa stain) or by immunofluorescence . The Gram stain is not useful.
  • In exudates, the organism can be identified within epithelial cells by fluorescent-antibody staining or hybridization with a DNA probe.

questions.text: A patient has periodic episodes of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia. Which of the following would be most suitable for outpatient prophylaxis?
questions.solution: Verapamil, a non dihydropyridine Ca channel blocker (CCB), depresses both the S-A node and the A-V node and would be effective for prophylaxis of paroxysmal atrial or supraventricular tachycardia. Nifedipine, the prototypic dihydropyridine CCB, has little effect on SVT. If we chose a fast-/immediate-acting dosage form of nifedipine, we would probably trigger substantial reflex cardiac stimulation. The increased sympathetic tone to the heart could worsen the PSVT. (And, although nitroglycerin is mainly a venodilator, it too could trigger reflex cardiac activation and worsen matters.) Lidocaine and adenosine are parenteral drugs with short half-lives and, thus, are not suitable for prophylactic therapy. Adenosine is considered as DOC for PSVT in unstable patients

questions.text: The prevalence of Candida glabrata infection is found to be 80% in a sample of 100. If the test is repeated for 95% confidence levels, then what will be the range of prevalence for the Candida glabrata infection?
questions.solution:
The range obtained by repeating a test is given by the formula:

p ± 2 √p (100-p) / n

where,

p = prevalence of disease

n = sample size used for the present study

In this particular example,

p = 80

n = 100.

Hence, the range estimated would be =

80 ± 2 √80 (100-20) / 100

= 80 ± 2 x 4

= 80 ± 8

= 72 to 88 %

questions.text: Which of the following diuretic can be given to prevent urate nephropathy in patient suffering from gout and taking a uricosuric drug?
questions.solution:
The risk of urate nephropathy can be reduced by increasing uric acid solubility in urine and reducing its reabsorption in kidney tubule. Uric acid becomes more soluble(less likely to precipitate or reabsorbed) as local pH rises. Recall that normal urine is acidic. By alkalinizing the urine, which is precisely what acetazolamide does, we can reduce the risk of reabsorption and hence stone formation. Note that acetazolamide is only an adjunct, and in addition to (or instead of) using it, we might also administer sodium bicarbonate, which will alkalinize the urine. Maintaining adequate hydration to help form relatively large volumes of a dilute urine is important.

Allopurinol, the xanthine oxidase inhibitor that blocks urate synthesis, can be (often is) used for prophylaxis. However, it takes some time to lower serum urate levels and so would be of little immediate value when urate stone formation is imminent or has occurred. Moreover, allopurinol does not change urine pH.

Loopd diuretic like furosemide, ethacrynic acid and thiazides diuretics can result in uric acid retention in plasma and hence hyperuricemia

questions.text: A 25 years old asymptomatic pregnant female underwent a pre-op coagulation test. Her bleeding time is 3 minutes, PT is 15/14sec, a PTT is 45/35 sec, platelet count is 2.5 lac/ mm3 and factor VIII levels were 60IU/dL. What is her most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Analyzing all the options one by one

  •  Option ‘a’… Factor IX deficiency would have resulted in increased aPTT. However females are less likely to suffer from hemophilia B because it is an X-linked disease. Additionally, the lady is pregnant. This favours an autoimmune etiology. 
  • Option ‘b’….. Lupus anticoagulant (Wintrobe 12th/1452, Harrison 18th/982) clearly says that these patients have thrombocytopenia (here platelet count is normal), prolonged PTT and hypoprothrombinemia due to antibodies against prothrombin (normal in this case) 
  • Option ‘c’….Factor VIII inhibitors (Wintrobe 12th/1441- 1444, Harrison 18th/982); Tejender Singh hematology page no 308) Acquired coagulant inhibitor is immune-mediated condition characterized by autoantibody against a specific clotting factor and factor VIII is most common target.  In 50% of patients no underlying disease is indentified at the time of diagnosis. In remaining the causes are autoimmune disease, malignancies, dermatologic diseases, pregnancy and post partum. Diagnosed by isolated prolongation of PTT with normal PT (coagulation profile is similar to haemophilia A). Platelet count and bleeding time is normal (matches with the data given in our question). 
  • Option ‘d’…. VWD – type III (Robbins 8th/672-3): Bleeding time will be prolonged (in this patient BT is normal) with abnormal platelet count. So, option‘d’ is excluded.v

 

So the likely diagnosis for the patient in the stem of the question is presence of acquired coagulation inhibitors against Factor VIII.
