questions.text: During the autopsy of a homicide victim, the doctor notices a circular wound on the left temporal area with a crater-like outer table and a punched-out inner table. There is no evidence of singing of hair or tattooing present. There are also tissue tags along the irregular edges of the wound. What type of wound is the doctor observing?
questions.solution:
Option D: Exit wound

  • The exit wound on the inner table shows a clean-cut hole and beveling on the outer table.
  • The wound is larger than the entry wound due to the deformity and tumbling of the bullet on entering the skull.
  • The beveling helps to assess the angle of fire.

Option A: Chop wound

  • Chop wound: Most of the injuries are homicidal, and usually inflicted on the exposed portions of the body, like the head, face, neck, shoulders and extremities.
  • A chop wound is considered a combination of blunt and sharp force injury.
  • Margins are sharp and may show abrasion, bruising and some laceration with severe injury to the underlying organs.

Option B: Pond fracture

  • Pond or indented fracture: This is a smooth concave depression without a fracture line, resulting from in-buckling of the skull, occurring only in the elastic skull of infants and children (prior to 4 years of age).

Option C: Entrance wound

  • The entry wound shows a punched-out hole (clean cut) on the outer table and a bevelled appearance on the inner table (as it remains unsupported, chipping of the bone occurs).
  • The fissured fracture may radiate from the hole.
  • The piece may be driven inside causing injury to the brain.
  • Dura shows irregular tears.
  • In contact wounds, shattering of the skull wound may occur.

questions.text: A researcher wants is to investigate which type of iron tablets  middle age women prefer. The investigator visits a pharmacy. There are many women in the place but the investigator goes to only those women who appear of middle age group and ask them to participate in his research. What type of sampling technique is this:-
questions.solution:
He had set the criteria for his elements i.e. they should be women, and should be of middle age. Purposive sampling is used :

  • First, in emergency situations, a case study may be conducted when rapid information about a condition is required, for example, the case study of a person or a family affected by a rare or ‘new’ illness that may be potentially contagious; or a unique event that could seriously affect large numbers of people.         
  • Second, in non-emergency situations, a case study approach is commonly used in exploratory research: that is in situations where the social phenomenon is new or never studied before and the researchers wish to familiarize themselves with the nature of the phenomenon in order to plan a more comprehensive and systematic study.

questions.text: A 42-yrs-old female , is diagnosed with metastatic breast cancer. Why might fulvestrant be the better choice over tamoxifen provided all other factors being equal?

choices.text: Exerts antiplatelet, rather than thrombotic effects
Lacks ability to cause hot flashes or other disturbing side effects
Lower risk of causing endometrial cancer
Provides clinical cure, rather than palliation, in all patients

questions.solution:
Fulvestrant is associated with a much lower risk of causing endometrial pathology, including cancer. It is a“pure” estrogen antagonist. That effect, in breast tissue, is what accounts for the drug’s beneficial effects in some patients with metastatic, estrogen-supported, breast cancer. In contrast, tamoxifen, raloxifene are classified as selective estrogen receptor modifiers (SERMs). Although they block estrogen receptors in breast tissue (just as fulvestrant does), they also have estrogenic (agonist) activity in some other tissues, notably the uterus. There they can cause endometrial proliferation, hyperplasia, and (apparently) an increased risk of endometrial cancer.

Because fulvestrant lacks estrogen agonist activity, it will not enhance bone mineralization nor favorably modify cholesterol profiles, as the SERMs tend to do. The SERMs slightly increase the risk of thromboembolism. Fulvestrant may too, but it also lacks any ability to prevent platelet aggregation or thromboembolism. Hot flashes are fairly common with any of these drugs.

questions.text: A 40-year old woman presents with endometrial carcinoma. Her family history reveals her mother died of endometrial cancer at age of 45 and her 38-year old brother has been recently diagnosed of colon cancer. You begin to suspect a familial cancer syndrome. What gene is most likely to be mutated?
questions.solution:
• Hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC) (Lynch Syndrome) syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by familial carcinomas of the colon affecting predominantly the cecum and proximal colon.
  • It results from defects in a family of genes encoding a group of proteins that work together to carry out DNA mismatch repair
  • Germline mutations in the MSH2 and MLH1 genes each account for approximately 30% of cases.
  • Endometrial carcinoma is the most common extracolonic cancer occurring in Lynch syndrome

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presents with a 2-week history of a skin rash over her buttocks and legs and joint pain. The parents report seeing blood in the urine. Physical examination reveals palpable purpuric skin lesions and markedly swollen knees. The results of laboratory studies reveal abnormally high erythrocyte sedimentation rate (30 mm/h), BUN of 25 mg/dL and serum creatinine of 3 mg/dL. Urinalysis demonstrates RBCs and RBC casts. The stool guaiac test is positive. Biopsy of lesional skin reveals deposits of IgA in the walls of small blood vessels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Henoch Schönlein purpura is the most common type of childhood vasculitis
  • Characterized by involvement of kidneys, skin, GIT & IgA deposition.
  • This childhood syndrome consists of purpuric skin lesions, abdominal pain and intestinal bleeding, and arthralgias along with renal abnormalities.
    • Skin lesions characteristically involve the extensor surfaces of arms and legs as well as buttocks
    • Abdominal manifestations include pain, vomiting, and intestinal bleeding.
    • The renal manifestations occur in one third of patients and include gross or microscopic hematuria, nephritic syndrome, nephrotic syndrome, or some combination of these.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is healthy but has a family history of colon cancer with onset at a young age. There are no abnormal physical examination findings. He undergoes colonoscopy and there are over 200 tubular adenomas ranging in size from 0.2 to 1 cm on gross inspection and microscopic examination of biopsies. Which of the following genetic diseases is he most likely to have?
questions.solution: Persons with familial polyposis caused by inheritance of an abnormal APC gene should have a total colectomy for this reason. By late childhood to young adulthood, one or more of the polyps will give rise to adenocarcinoma. The polyps do not occur elsewhere in the GI tract.

questions.text: A 14 year old boy present with headache, fever and cough for 2 days. Sputum is scant and non-purulent and gram stain reveals many white cells but no organisms. The treatment should be initiated with ?
questions.solution:
Macrolides : are 2nd line drug to penicillin.
- Erythromycin,
- Clarithromycin
- Roxithromycin
- Azithromycin
- Fidaxomicin: pseudomembranous colitis(PMC)

Macrolide are DOC for :
- C: Chancroid
- L: Legionella
- A: Atypical pneumonia
- P: Pertusis or whooping cough

Macrolide also cause stimulation of motilin receptor, therefore can be used in treatment of diabetic gastroparesis.

Azithromycin:
- Very long acting macrolide
- Do not inhibit microsomal enzyme unlike other macrolide. Therefore azithromycin has very less drug interaction.

questions.text: You see a 20-year old female for complaints of vaginal itching, discharge, pain with intercourse and discomfort with urination. She has had 3 different sexual partners over the past 2 years. As part of your workup, you do a wet mount of vaginal secretions and see a flagellated organism about the size of a white blood cell with "twitching motility" that makes you think of Trichomonas vaginalis. Which statement is false regarding Trichomonas?

choices.text: Men are most likely asymptomatic but efficient transmitters of this organism
The cyst form of the life cycle is the most common method of transmission
Simultaneous treatment of the patient and her sexual contacts will decrease the chance of recurrences
In severe cases the regional mucosa may be red with petechial lesions and the cervix has been described as a "strawberry cervix"

questions.solution:
There is only one stage in the life cycle of Trichomonas, trophozoite.

Hence, the transmission occurs sexually via the trophozoite.

T. vaginalis inhabits the lower genital tract of females and the urethra and prostate of males.

Men infected with T. vaginalis are usually asymptomatic but can transmit the infection sexually.

In contrast, infection in women, which has an incubation period of 5–28 days, is usually symptomatic and manifests with malodorous vaginal discharge (often yellow), vulvar erythema and itching, dysuria or urinary frequency.

All sexual partners must be treated concurrently (Metronidazole) to prevent reinfection, especially from asymptomatic males.

questions.text: A severely burned firefighter develops a rapidly disseminating bacterial infection while hospitalized. “Green pus” is noted in the burned tissue and culture of the tissue yielded growth as shown in the image. The gram stain of the growth revealed small oxidase-positive gram-negative rods. Which of the following statements most accurately convey information about this organism?

choices.text: Endotoxin is the only virulence factor known to be produced by these bacteria
Humans are the only known reservoir hosts for these bacteria
The bacteria are difficult to culture because they have numerous growth requirements
These are among the most antibiotic resistant of all clinically relevant bacteria

questions.solution:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an obligate aerobe that grows on many types of culture media, sometimes producing a sweet or grape like odor. It often produces a non fluorescent bluish pigment (pyocyanin) which diffuses into agar or pus fluids. Many strains also produce afluorescent pigment (pyoverdin), which gives a greenish color. One of the most significant problems with Pseudomonas infections is the high level of natural resistance to many antimicrobials that this widespread environmental opportunist exhibits.

Features of Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

  • Gram negative bacilli
  • Catalase positive
  • Oxidase positive: change of color From white to blue within 10 sec → Positive

VIRULENCE FACTORS:

  • Capsular Polysaccharide
  • Alginic Acid
  • Pigments are:-
  • Pyocyanin → Blue
  • Pyorubin → Red
  • Pyomelanin → Black
  • Pyoverdin → Green

These pigments enhance on King's Media.

questions.text: 36 year male Weighing 70kg patient a drug X . Cpss of drug is 6 mg/L and Oral bioavailability is 50%, Volume of distribution 2 L/kg, Clearance of 80 ml/hr/kg and Plasma half life of 10 hours. calculate maintainance dose of drug X ?
questions.solution:
Maintenance dose = target plasma concentration X clearance / F

So we need to use only some values given in the question. Rest are given to confuse you.

Target plasma concentration (Cpss) of drug = 6 mg/L

Oral bioavailability (F) is 50% = 0.5

Clearance = 80 ml/hr/kg =

= 80 X 70

= 5600 ml/hr

= 5.6 L/hr

Maintenance dose = target plasma concentration X clearance / F

= 6 x 5.6/ 0.5

= 33.6/0.5

= 67. 20 mg/hr

questions.text: A new regimen used in patients with bladder carcinoma is tested in a clinical trial. Among 50 patients treated with this new regimen, 25 survive 5 years without relapse. Out of 100 patients treated with the conventional regimen, 25 survive 5 years without showing any relapse. How many patients need to be treated with the new regimen as opposed to conventional regimen in order for 1 more patient to survive 5 years without relapse?
questions.solution:
Relapse No Relapse
New Rx 25 25
Convential Rx 75 25
  • Rt (INCIDENCE IN exposed) = a/ (a +b)
  • Rnt (incidence in non-exposed) = c/ (c+d)
  • ARR (Attributable risk) = Rnt – Rt (INCIDENCE IN non-exposed- incidence in exposed)
  • NNT = 1/ ARR
Event No event
Treatment A B
Control C D
Event (replace) No event (no relapse)
Treatment(50) A(25) B(25)
Control (100) C(75) D (25)
  • Rt = 25/ 50
  • Rnt = 75/ 100
  • ARR = 0.75- 0.5=0.25
  • NNT = 1/ 0.25 = 4

questions.text: In the course of T—lymphocyte maturation, T cell receptors of several lymphocytes demonstrate a very high affinity interaction with MHC molecules expressed on thymic medullary epithelial and dendritic cells. This is named as ?
questions.solution:
• T-lymphocytes, or thymocytes are initially produced in the bone marrow: but they migrate from that location to mature during the first trimester of gestation in the thymus.
  • In the thymus the processes of T-cell receptor (TCR) gene rearrangement positive selection, negative selection and expression of extracellular membrane markers and co-stimulatory molecules occurs.
  • Pro-T cells arrive at the thymus as “double negative” cells indicating that they lack both CD4 and CD8 antigens and begin their differentiation in the subcapsular zone.
  • Next the process of TCR beta gene rearrangement occurs with simultaneous expression of both CD4 and CD8.
  • Once in thymic cortex the alpha genes rearrange to produce functional alpha-beta TCR.
  • Subsequently, the processes of positive and negative selection occur with cells that fail either of these tests being eliminated by apoptosis.

questions.text: 44 year old man admitted with a road traffic accident and wound is shown in the image. As per the history he was vaccinated 4 years before for tetanus. As per the current guideline what should be the appropriate prophylactic measurement for tetanus?
questions.solution:
• Contaminated wound.
  • Vaccinated less than 5years, no need of Vaccine / Tig
  • Wound toileting and antibiotics are useful.

TYPES OF BITES:

→ CLASS I BITTES : No prophylaxis required.

  • Licks over intact skin

→ CLASS II BITES: Post exposure prophylaxis required.

  • Licks over broken skin
  • No oozing of Blood

→ CLASS III BITES :Post exposure prophylaxis+ Igs

  • Facial Bites
  • Constant oozing of blood
  • Untraceable animal after bite
  • Wild animals bites

Management:

  1. Wound should never be stitched immediately to prevent additional trauma that may help in spread of the virus in the deeper tissue.
  2. “If suturing is necessary, then it has to be done after 24-48 hrs later, applying minimum stitches under the coverage of anti rabies serum locally”- Park.
  3. Cleansing – wound should be scrubbed well immediately with soap & water– soap kills the virus effectively.
  4. Chemical treatment- wound is treated with quaternary ammonium compounds (like cetavlon or tincture iodine).
  5. Category III (Major risk):
  • Recommended prophylaxis (WHO)- Wound management, Rabies immunoglobulin, Rabies vaccine, Observe the dog for 10 days.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female presents to the outpatient department with complaints of chronic fatigue and bluish nose and lips for one week. She had a history of mild respiratory infection two weeks back. Physical examination reveals signs of pallor. Her vitals are within normal limits. CBC shows anaemia, increased MCV, increased reticulocyte, and increased LDH. Direct Coombs test is positive for C3d. A peripheral blood smear showed the following image. What is the most likely cause of the findings seen?

choices.text: Clumps of RBCs due to IgM mediated cold autoim­mune haemolytic anemia
Clumps of RBCs due to IgG mediated warm auto­immune haemolytic anemia
Clumps of RBCs due to IgG mediated cold autoim­mune haemolytic anemia

questions.solution:
Option A: Clumps of RBCs due to IgM-mediated cold autoim­mune haemolytic anaemia

  • This is the case of cold agglutinin haemolytic anaemia (cold AIHA), in which the patient presents with signs and symptoms of pallor, chronic fatigue, and cyanosis of the nose with blue lips. This indicates the presence of sluggish circulation.
  • Lab workup shows anaemia, increased MCV, increased reticulocytes, and increased LDH giving strong evidence of a haemolytic crisis.
  • The peripheral smear shows agglutination of RBCs and is occurring in December.
  • This is highly suggestive of cold-mediated agglutination of RBCs seen in cold AIHA.
  • Positive direct Coombs test (DAT) for C3d confirms the diagnosis.
  • Cold AIHA results from binding IgM autoantibodies to I antigen of RBCs in vascular beds when the temperature falls below 30°C resulting in agglutination of RBCs and sluggish blood flow, which leads to cyanosis of exposed fingers, toes, ears, and nose.
  • As the blood recirculates & warms, IgM is released, usually before complement-mediated hemolysis can occur.

Option B: Clumps of RBCs due to IgG-mediated warm auto­immune haemolytic anaemia

  • In cold agglutinin disease, IgM-mediated cold antibodies bind to the RBC antigens resulting in the clumping of RBCs leading to extravascular hemolysis.
  • Warm autoantibodies are usually seen in patients with severe anaemia and negative DAT test.

Option C: RBC lysis due to hemoglobinopathy

  • Haemoglobinopathies result in intrinsic haemolytic anaemia due to genetic mutations leading to intrinsic defects in the erythrocyte wall/membrane. This causes increased RBC lysis. 
  • Peripheral blood smear usually shows abnormally shaped RBCs more prone to damage.
  • This includes haemoglobin C disease, sickle cell anaemia, thalassemia, etc.

Option D: Clumps of RBCs due to IgG-mediated cold autoim­mune haemolytic anaemia

  • Cold AIHA is caused by the release of IgM-mediated autoimmune antibodies, which then bind to RBCs resulting in the clumping of RBCs.
  • Direct Coombs test is usually IgG negative.

questions.text: A young adult came with casualty with history of some substance abuse. His pulse was 110 beats per minute, respiratory rate 30/min, blood gas analysis revealed metabolic acidosis, hypocalcemia and electrolyte imbalance. Blood urea – 100 mg/dl, creatinine – 3.4 mg/dl. Urine analysis showed calcium oxalate crystals. He improved on gastric lavage, ethanol, sodium bicarbonate, calciumg luconate and 4-methyl pyrazole. What is the substance he consumed?
questions.solution:
Ethylene glycol; also called antifreeze. It is a clear, colorless, odourless, non-volatile liquid with a bitter-sweet taste. MOA – Toxicity through metabolites, i.e. glycolic and oxalic acids which inhibit oxidative phosphorylation.

CLINICAL FEATURES

  • Tachycardia, tachypnoea and congestive heart failure
  • Hypocalcemia, electrolyte imbalance and metabolic acidosis (due to glycolic acid)
  • Oxaluria, acute tubular necrosis, renal failure and Calcium oxalate crystals (due to oxalic acid).

TREATMENT (SIMILAR TO METHANOL POSIONING)

  • Gastric lavage, sodium bicarbonate (to combat acidosis), calcium gluconate (to correct hypocalcemia)
  • Ethanol or 4 methyl pyrazole (fomepizole) as antidote
  • Hemodialysis in cases of severe poisoning. PM APPEARANCE
  • Oxalate crystals are seen in the brain, spinal cord and kidneys (Note: Metabolic acidosis also seen with methanol but calcium oxalate crystals with renal failure are characteristic of Ethylene glycol)

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer comes to the outpatient department with the complaint of fever off and on for the past 4 years. He also complains of headache and body aches. He is diagnosed as a case of chronic brucellosis. Which of the following test is used to diagnose the serology of this disease?
questions.solution:
Option A: Standard agglutination test

  • The patient, in this case, is diagnosed with brucellosis.
  • It is caused by brucella specie, a gram-negative coccobacilli.
  • Its clinical features are
    • Flu-like symptoms
    • Night sweats
    • Undulant fever
    • Painful lymphadenopathy
  • Diagnostic:
    • Rose bengal test
    • Standard agglutination test
    • ELISA
    • Milk ring test
  • Standard agglutination test
  • It is also called the tube agglutination test
  • It is used for brucellosis screening and widal tests.
  • CFT and ELISA are preferred in chronic brucellosis for Ab detection.

Option B: Western blotting

  • This test is used to confirm the diagnosis of positive HIV.
  • It is also used to separate and identify proteins.

Option C: Complement fixation test

  • It is used to detect some viral, fungal and rickettsia diseases.
  • It is widely used to detect infections, particularly in microbes.
  • It is used to detect specific antibodies in the serum

Option D: VDRL

  • Venereal Disease Research Laboratory test is a nontreponemal test.
  • It is used to detect serology in syphilis.
  • It is a screening test for syphilis.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman, who has been followed for the past 25 years for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) comes to the emergency department complaining of 48 hours of temperatures to 38.6 C (101.4 F) and worsening shortness of breath. She has a chronic productive cough, which has become more copious. On physical examination, she has rhonchi and increased fremitus in the posterior mid-lung field. A Gram's stain reveals many epithelial cells and multiple gram-positive and gram-negative organisms; no neutrophils are seen. Which of the following is the most likely organism causing the symptoms?
questions.solution:
• This patient, with a long history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), has evidence of a community-acquired pneumonia.
  • The common organisms causing pneumonias in patients with COPD are Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis.
  • This patient has no other history suggestive of Escherichia coli infection elsewhere (such as in the urinary tract), and primary E. coli pneumonia is rare. Klebsiella pneumoniae is typically found in alcoholic patients and it may cavitate. There is no evidence of tuberculosis by history.

Tuberculosis usually presents with a more chronic presentation. Furthermore, it would generally be found as an upper lobe infiltrate, consistent with reactivation tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 33 yr old female with chronic backache comes to OPD. On X ray she appeared to have a D12 collapse, But the Intervertebral disc space is well maintained. All are possible in this scenario except
questions.solution: Tuberculosis As a rule neoplastic and traumatic/osteoporotic collapse show sparing of the intervertebral disc, while tuberculosis classically is paradiscal, involvement of disc is usual. Common neoplasms in adult causing disc collapse are metastasis and multiple myeloma, while in children vertebral collapse may indicate histiocytosis (vertebra plana).

questions.text: A 75 year old patient with coronary artery disease , hypertension and COPD is undergoing a left colectomy for cancer. He had a COPD exacerbation 4 months ago and was on steroids for a week at the time. Steroid replacement

choices.text: Should Be Given At A Dose Grater Than 10 Times The Normal Daily Cortisol Production Rate
Should Not Exceed 100-150 Mg Of Cortisol Equivalent Per Day
Is Not Necessary In This Patient
Should Include 100mg Of Cortisol Tapered Over 5-7 Days

questions.solution:
• Preoperative steroid therapy causes adreno cortical suppression and the patient wont be able to cope up with the surgical stress.
  • That is why we need to supplement steroids in pre operative period.
  • This applies to only those patients who have a depressed adrenal system
  • In this patient steroid therapy was initiated long time back that too for a brief period of a week and the stopped.
  • So this patient doesn’t require steroid replacement.

questions.text: A 25 year old male comes with history of tremors. His tremors seems to improve over period of time as shown in the image. Which of the following drug could have brought improvement in his symptom?
questions.solution:
• In the image shown patient is drawing Archemedian spiral .In the first image patient had zig zag all throughout the movement which means was present at rest suggestive of essential tremors.
  • ET is the commonest movement disorder, affecting approximately 5–10 million persons . It can present in childhood, but dramatically increases in prevalence over the age of 70 years. ET is characterized by a high-frequency tremor (up to 11 Hz) that predominantly affects the upper extremities. The tremor is most often manifest as a postural or kinetic tremor. It is typically bilateral and symmetric, but may begin on one side and remain asymmetric.
  • Tremor involves the head in 30% of cases, voice in 20%, tongue in 20%, face/jaw in 10%, and lower limbs in 10%. The tremor is characteristically improved by alcohol and worsened by stress.
  • Many cases are mild and require no treatment other than reassurance. Occasionally, tremor can be severe and interfere with eating, writing, and activities of daily living. This is more likely to occur as the patient ages and is often associated with a reduction in tremor frequency.
  • Blockers or primidone are the standard drug therapies for ET and help in about 50% of cases.
  • Propranolol (20–80 mg daily, given in divided doses) is usually effective at relatively low doses, but higher doses may be effective in some patients. The drug is contraindicated in patients with bradycardia or asthma.

Hand tremor tends to be most improved, while head tremor is often refractory. Primidone can be helpful, but should be started at low doses (12.5 mg) and gradually increased (125–250 tid) to avoid sedation.

questions.text: 20-year-old female patient with a history of asthma is undergoing annual examination. Currently, she feels well. She has never been pregnant. Which of these types of pelvic examination is most appropriate at this time?

choices.text: Speculum examination of the vagina and cervix
Bimanual examination of the adnexa, uterus, and ovaries
Pelvic screening is not indicated at this time

questions.solution: Pelvic screening is not indicated at this time. The American College of Physicians recommends against pelvic screening examination in non-pregnant, asymptomatic adults.

questions.text: Which is the imaging diagnosis in a case of middle aged patient with acute abdominal pain
questions.solution:
Acute appendicitis

CT is highly sensitive (94-98%) and specific (up to 97%) for the diagnosis of acute appendicitis and allows for alternative causes of abdominal pain also to be diagnosed. The need for contrast (IV, oral or both) is debatable and varies from institution to institution. Oral contrast has not been shown to increase the sensitivity of CT . CT findings include : appendiceal dilatation (>6 mm diameter) wall thickening (>3 mm) and enhancement thickening of the cecal apex: cecal bar sign, arrowhead sign periappendiceal inflammation fat stranding thickening of the lateroconal fascia or mesoappendix extra luminal fluid phlegm on (inflammatory mass) abscess focal wall no enhancement representing necrosis (gangrenous appendicitis) and a precursor to perforation.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man is brought to the physician’s office by his wife because she has noted a personality change during the past 3 months. While the patient is being interviewed, he answers every question with the same three words. Which of the following symptoms best fits this patient’s behavior?
questions.solution:
Perseveration persistence of the same response beyond the point of relevance is perseveration. Same reflects perseveration.

  • Perseveration is the repetition of the same response, beyond the point of relevance.
  • It is in response to a question and is not spontaneous.
  • It can be a feature of schizophrenia but isn't characteristic.
  • It can also be seen in organic mental disorders

HOW TO REMEMBER: The term originally meant “resolve” or “determination” and comes from the Latin persev meaning “perseverance”.

questions.text:
An audiogramof an individualis given below Degree of hearing handicap is ?



Ear
500 Hz
1000 Hz
2000 Hz


Right
30 db
30 db
60 db


Left
30 db
45 db
60 db
questions.solution:
Steps of calculating Degree of hearing handicap

Calculate the average of thresholds of hearing for frequencies of 500,1000, and 2000 Hz.

Deduct from it 25 db. Multiply it by 1.5 .

This is the percentage of hearing impairment for that ear. Similarly calculate the percentage of hearing impairment of the other ear.

Percentage handicap of an individual is

( better ear % × 5) + worse ear %

= 6

Ear 500 Hz 1000 Hz 2000 Hz
Right 30 db 30 db 60 db
Left 30 db 45 db 60 db

Impairment Rt ear : 40– 25 = 15 ; 15 × 1.5 = 22.5 %

Impairment Lt ear : 45 – 25 = 20 ; 20 × 1.5 = 30 %

( 22.5 × 5 ) + 30

Total handicap = 6

= 142.5 ÷ 6 = 23.75

= 24 %(rounded off )

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presents with several weeks history of headache and difficulties with speech. A sister who lives with her claims that her language “has recently not been making much sense” and that she is a bit confused. Her condition seems to be deteriorating. On neurologic examination, she has a moderately severe aphasia, with difficulty understanding language and following commands, and she makes frequent paraphasic errors when she speaks. There are no other motor or sensory deficits. An MRI with intravenous contrast reveals the presence of a ring-enhancing mass lesion within the substance of the left temporal lobe. The lesion is approximately 3 cm in greatest diameter, poorly demarcated from the surrounding brain, and surrounded by a moderate amount of cerebral edema. Findings on routine admission tests, including chest x-ray and serum biochemistry are unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Metastasis to the brain from an occult primary cancer

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is glioblastoma multiforme

Glioblastoma multiforme

Most common primary malignant brain tumour in adults. It is a WHO grade IV astrocytoma which accounts for the majority of high grade astrocytomas. These tend to arise from lower grade tumours (secondary glioblastomas) and have a better prognosis

They usually presents in the sixth and seventh decades of life with headache , seizures, focal deficits and personality changes

Imaging demonstrates a ring enhancing lesion with central necrosis, surrounding edema and mass effect. These are highly infiltrative tumours and the areas of increased T2/FLAIR signal surrounding the main tumour mass contain invading tumour cells

Treatment involves gross total resection with postoperative chemotherapy and radiation therapy. Temozolomide is the current drug of choice. Median survival for glioblastoma remains just over 12 months

Meningioma

On imaging studies they have a characteristic appearance usually of a densely enhancing extra axial tumour arising from the dura. Typically they have a dural tail, consisting of thickened enhanced dura extending like a tail from the mass

Brain metastasis

MRI pre- and post- contrast administration is the study of choice for evaluation. These lesions are typically well circumscribed, round and multiple

questions.text: 33-year-old woman comes to the emergency room with the chief complaint that she has been hearing voices for 7 months. When asked the meaning of the proverb “People in glass houses should not throw stones,” the patient replies, “Because the windows would break.” Which of the following mental status findings does this patient display?
questions.solution: Concrete thinking Proverb test is used for abstract ability, giving literal meaning of proverb and not in depth explanation, points towards concretisation of thinking.

questions.text: A female patient presents with diffuse alopecia to dermatological clinic with her husband. She had suffered from typhoid fever 3 months back. Most probable diagnosis is ?
questions.solution: Telogen effluvium is the name for temporary hair loss on all parts of your body, but generally, only loss of scalp hair is symptomatic due to shedding of resting or telogen hair after some shock to your system. New hair continues to grow. Telogen hair has a bulb or club-shaped tip.

questions.text: A boy having unilateral nasal obstruction with epistaxis for several months. ON CT PNS, it is found to have enhancing lesion with minimal extension to sphenoid sinus & no lateral extension. Comment on the stage of tumor?
questions.solution:
FISCH STAGING CLASSIFICATION

Done for prognosis and therapeutic approaches

Stage 1: tumor limited to the nasal cavity

Stage 2: Tumor extension into the pterygopalatine fossa, or maxillary, sphenoid or ethmoid sinuses.

Stage3 a: Tumor extension into the orbit or infratemporal fossa without intracranial involvement.

Stage3b: stage IIIa with extadural (parasellar) intracraninal involvement

Stage4a: Inradural without cavernous sinus, pituitary, or optic chiasm involvement

Stage4b:Involvement of the cavernous sinus, pituitary, or optic chiasm

questions.text: A 69-year-old diabetic man presents to the acute surgery unit with a 5-day history of mild dysuria and increased frequency of urine. On examination, he is found to be pyrexic and tachycardic. A genital examination reveals both the penis and the scrotum to be swollen, red and tender to touch, with erythema also extending into the groin bilaterally. Of note, the examining surgeon believes that there is palpable crepitus in the perineum. Routine blood investigations and cultures are taken (which later grow both aerobic and anaerobic organisms), and fluid resuscitation and broad-spectrum antibiotics are commenced. Following further discussion with a urologist, he is taken promptly into the operating theatre for definitive management. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is ?
questions.solution:
Fournier’s gangrene

Fournier’s gangrene is a necrotizing fascitis of the male genitalia and perineum (secondary to infection by aerobic and anaerobic bacteria), affecting predominantly middle-aged and elderly men with pre-existing co-morbidities

It is a urological emergency that often presents with swelling, pain and erythema of the genital region which may progress to discolouration and frank necrosis accompanied by systemic features such as fever and rigour

The presence of crepitus is virtually diagnostic

It is usually a polymicrobial infection with microaerobes, anaerobes and gram positive and gram negative organisms. It spreads along Dartos, Scarpa’s and Colles’ fascia

Risk factors for development include peripheral vascular disease, diabetes mellitus, malnutrition, alcoholism and other immunocompromised states

Given the potential for rapid spread and tissue destruction, early diagnosis and urgent surgical drainage with aggressive debridement of the necrotic tissue is an essential component of management, along with broad-spectrum antibiotic cover

It is rare for the infection to involve the testicles or deep tissues of the penis because of the tunica vaginalis and Buck fascia respectively, so these structures should be preserved

It is uncommon for the urethra to be involved, although a defined urinary tract source may be evident such as urethral stricture with perforation and local infection

Mortality is high and related to the level of existing co-morbidity

Epididymo orchitis results when the urinary tract infection ascends through the vas deferens into the epididymis or testicle. Clinical features include urinary symptoms like frequency, urgency, dysuria and fever. But the patient is not tachycardic and erythema and tenderness does not extend into the groin and crepitus is absent

Testicular tumour is the most common cause of cancer in men aged 20 to 40 years. Most patients present with testicular pain or a testicular mass. Respiratory symptoms, back pain, weight loss or gynecomastia may indicate metastatic disease (10-20%). A testicular mass is considered malignant till proven otherwise

Testicular torsion

The most common cause of the acute scrotum is testicular torsion. It occurs when arterial blood supply is compromised by a twist of the spermatic cord creating occlusion of the spermatic cord and loss of vascular supply. When torsion occurs , the testicle is subjected to warm ischemia; without reversal of the occluded blood supply ,irreversible changes begin as soon as 4 hours and is complete by 8 to 12 hours. Clinical findings include sudden onset of intense unilateral scrotal pain, unrelated to trauma that may be associated with nausea and vomiting. The most consistent physical examination finding is loss of the cremasteric reflex of the testicle. The testis that has undergone torsion may be high riding, edematous and significantly tender

questions.text: A 50 year old lady complains of discomfort and dragging of her right foot while walking and difficulty in wearing slippers .This could be due to injury to which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
COMMON PERONEAL NERVE INJURY-RELATED TO FIBULAR NECK!

Motor

Muscles of anterior and lateral compartments of leg are paralyzed namely—tibialis anterior, extensor digitorum longus and brevis, extensor hallucis longus and peroneus tertius (supplied by deep peroneal nerve) and peroneus longus and brevis (supplied by superficial peroneal nerve)—presenting as foot drop.

Sensory

  • Loss of sensation down the anterior and lateral sides of leg and dorsum of foot and toes, including medial side of big toe.

Fig. Foot drop—CPN palsy

Fig. Foot drop splint

  • Lateral border of foot and lateral side of little toe are unaffected (sural nerve mainly formed from tibial nerve).
  • The medial border of foot as far as the ball of big toe is completely unaffected (saphenous nerve, a branch of femoral nerve).

questions.text: A primigravida has delivered her baby one hour ago but has not yet delivered the placenta and is bleeding. The management of choice should be ?
questions.solution:
This is retained placenta and treatment is removal under GA. Failure of placental delivery within 60 minutes after delivery if the fetus. Management If the placentais undelivered after 30 minutes consider:

  • Emptying bladder
  • Breastfeeding or nipple stimulation
  • Change of position - encourage an upright position

questions.text: Which of the following feature is not helpful in differentiating absence seizure from Complex partial seizure?
questions.solution:
Feature Absence Seizure Complex partial Seizure
Neurological status Normal May have positive history or examination

Post ictal phase No Confusion fatigue

Neuroimaging Normal May show focal lesion

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman complains of severe, acute onset left temporal headache and changes in left eye vision. She presents to her physician with sweating, malaise, and temperature of 99ºF. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Temporal arteritis

Giant cell arteritis, also known as temporal arteritis is a systemic chronic inflammatory disease. It usually occurs in patients older than 55 years. It is more common in women. The inflammatory process typically involves the aorta and its extracranial branches , of which the superficial temporal artery is specifically affected

The clinical syndrome begins with a prodromal phase of constitutional symptoms, including headache, fever, malaise and myalgia. As a result of vascular narrowing and end organ ischemia, complications may occur such as visual alterations, including blindness and mural weakness, resulting in acute aortic dissection that may be devastating. Ischemic optic neuritis resulting in partial or complete blindness may occur and is considered a medical emergency

A characteristic presentation is severe pain over the temporal artery that is frequently bilateral, with tenderness and nodularity of the artery

The diagnostic gold standard is a temporal artery biopsy, which will show the classic histologic findings of multinucleate giant cells with a dense perivascular inflammatory infiltrate. Treatment involves administration of corticosteroids

Takayasu’s arteritis

It is a chronic inflammatory arteritis which frequently affects the aorta, its major branches and the pulmonary artery. Lesions may be stenosis or aneurysmal degeneration. It occurs predominantly in women between the ages 10 and 40 years. Patient presents initially with constitutional symptoms like fever, anorexia and myalgia followed by a second stage of multiple arterial occlusive symptoms, depending on the location of disease involvement. The gold standard for diagnosis is angiography and treatment consists of steroid therapy

Kawasaki’s disease

It is an acute vasculitis with a predilection for involving the coronary arteries in children younger than 5 years with a peak incidence at 1 year of age. Boys are affected more commonly than girls. Coronary artery aneursyms, the hallmark of the disease, histologically demonstrate a panarteritis with fibrinoid necrosis. Treatment consists of intravenous gamma globulin and aspirin therapy

Polyarteritis Nodosa

It is characterised by a necrotic inflammation of medium sized or small arteries that spare the smallest blood vessels. It is more common in men. The arteries of the kidney, liver, heart and gastrointestinal tract are commonly affected. It is characterised by the formation of multiple visceral aneursyms with attendant risk of rupture. The main stay of treatment is steroid and cytotoxic agent therapy

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the OPD complaining of fatigue, weakness, painful swelling of the fingers and toes, pale-coloured skin, and dark urine. She also has a history of recurrent joint pains and infections. Her lab findings include decreased Hb, high reticulocyte count and sickled RBC on PBF. Which of the following is not true regarding this patient's condition?

choices.text: She can present with pulmonary bleeds

questions.solution:
Option C: She can present with pulmonary bleeds

  • This patient's anaemia with jaundice points to hemolytic anaemia, and joint pain indicates sickling leading to a vaso-occlusive crisis.
  • Moreover, the sickled RBC on lab findings suggests sickle cell anaemia.

Sickle cell anaemia:

  • It is an inherited blood disorder caused by a point mutation in the β-globin gene.
  • Mutant HbA is termed HbS (sickle haemoglobin).
  • Deoxygenated HbS polymerizes and causes sickling.
  • Pathogenesis: Low O2, high altitudes, dehydration, or acidosis triggers sickling.
  • Sickled RBCs precipitate in the blood vessel and cause vaso-occlusion.
  • Signs/Symptoms include:
    • Recurrent painful episodes.
    • Anaemia.
    • Painful swelling of hands and feet.
  • The major haemoglobin in sickle cell anaemia is HbS, and HbA will be undetectable.
  • Proliferative sickle retinopathy (PSR) is the most severe ocular change in SCD.
  • Patients can present with acute chest syndrome (not pulmonary syndrome).
  • Acute chest syndrome is characterized by chest pain, tachypnea, fever, cough, and arterial oxygen desaturation., pulmonary bleeds are not seen.
  • Treatment: Hydroxyurea
  • Increases foetal haemoglobin and reduces sickling.
  • Beneficial effects on RBC hydration.
  • Reduces vascular wall adherence of sticky reticulocytes.

Option A: HbA will be undetectable

  • The HbA is mutated in sickle cell anaemia, and the mutant form is termed HbS.
  • Therefore, HbA is almost undetectable in this condition.

Option B: She may have retinopathy

  • The most severe ocular change in sickle cell disease is proliferative sickle retinopathy.

Option D: Hydroxyurea would help her

  • The most effective oral treatment for sickle cell anaemia is hydroxyurea.
  • It reduces sickling by increasing the amount of fetal haemoglobin.

questions.text: Babu ram 45 years male who sustained a RTA is stabilized according to ATLS protocols taken to emergency ward and managed by an intern and gets the X-ray done which reveals fracture in shaft of femur (S.O.F). Patient is stabilized and supplied with O2& shifted to ward. After 4 hours of injury patient suffers from breathlessness & PaO2 56 mmHg, Then the patient is shifted to ICU; ABG done and supplemented with O2.What do you expect?
questions.solution:
• Even though all the above-mentioned clinical features suggest fat embolism syndrome. It takes at least 48 hours for thromboembolic phenomena to occur
  • Hence, it is not a Fatty embolism
  • So fracture in S.O.F, Breathlessness, Pao2 <60mmHg - all points to ARDS by eliminating other option

Fat embolism syndrome:

FAT EMBOLISM after fracture S.O.F

  • Mn- Fracture femur shaft + forty-eight hours = Fat embolism
  • Diagnostic criteria for fat embolism-Gurd’s Criteria

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding bedside ultrasound examination for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)?

choices.text: The minimum diameter for AAA is 5 cm
Ultrasound is not useful in detecting AAA rupture
Ultrasound is less accurate than CT in detecting AAA
Up to 90% of AAAs are superior to the renal arteries

questions.solution:
• While ultrasound is very accurate in measuring AAA size, it is often impossible to determine sonographically whether the AAA has ruptured, since rupture most often occurs into the retroperitoneal space.
  • Ultrasound is not a good imaging tool to detect retroperitoneal pathology. The aorta normally tapers as it progresses distally, and any diameter >3 cm is abnormal.
  • Approximately 90% of AAAs are located inferior to the renal arteries. Imaging this portion of the abdominal aorta can be difficult due to underlying small bowel gas.

Although pressure on the transducer usually displaces intervening bowel gas, complete visualization is sometimes impossible. Such examinations are considered indeterminate.

questions.text: A lady with previous LSCS presents with BP of 150/100 mmHG at 37-week gestation. On PV examination OS closed, cervix soft, posterior 50% effaced, station minus 3. Her pelvis is adequate. What is the best treatment?

choices.text: Appropriate rest, antihypertensive therapy, and wait for normal labor

questions.solution: In gestational hypertension, maternal BP reaches 140/90 or greater for the first time during pregnancy, and proteinuria is not present. In preeclampsia, BP increases to 140/90 after 20 weeks of gestation and proteinuria is present (300 mg in 24 h or 1+ protein or greater on dipstick). In a case of PIH, the pregnancy can be allowed to continue till 37 weeks (unless there is eclampsia or severe uncontrolled hyper- tension with impending eclampsia or HELLP syndrome where pregnancy has to be terminated irrespective of weeks of gestation). Thereafter, the pregnancy should be terminated even if the BP is under control, as the risks of continuation of pregnancy far outweigh the benefits (as delivery is the ultimate treatment for pregnancy-induced hypertension, and it is not advis- able to wait further because the BP can rise and there can be complications, and there are no added benefits of continuing pregnancy beyond 37 weeks). So the best management would be to terminate pregnancy at 37 completed weeks. Induction of labor in a case of previous LSCS can be done and cervical ripening can also be done and these are not direct indications of CS

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman has had irregular menstrual bleeding for the past 6 months. On physical examination there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show a negative pregnancy test. A D&C is performed and microscopic examination shows dyssynchronous endometrial glands and stroma of anovulatory cycles. Following the procedure she ceases to have menstrual bleeding. Which of the following is the most likely cause of absent menses ?
questions.solution:
Asherman syndrome

This is a very rare complication of a D&C procedure in which endometrium, including the stratum basalis, is removed. Endometriosis is best known as a cause for pelvic pain, though it may cause irregular menstrual cycles. It is unlikely to cause amenorrhea. Elevated prolactin levels can produce amenorrhea along with galactorrhea. The onset is not related to a D&C procedure. Ovarian failure is unlikely to have a relationship to a D&C. Oral contraceptives produce more regular cycles

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient has been brought to OPD by his family members with history of loosening of clothes at inappropriate places. There are several times when he laughs inappropriately during the interview. His speech is confusing and unpredictably shifts from one topic to another. There is also history of mirror gazing and giggling to self. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Hebephrenic Schizophrenia Mirror gazing, giggling, inappropriate laughter, and disorganized behaviour points towards diagnosis of hebephrenia.

According to DSM-IV, types of schizophrenia

Paranoid schizophrenia

  • Most common type
  • Characterized by predominant positive symptoms
  • Late onset and good prognosis

Catatonic schizophrenia

  • Predominant catatonic or motor symptoms
  • Best prognosis out of other schizophrenia
  • 1st line treatment – i.v lorazepam & electroconvulsive therapy

Disorganized / hebephrenic schizophrenia

  • Characterized by disorganized symptoms
  • Early onset with bad prognosis
  • Significant disorientation of personality

Simple schizophrenia

  • Predominant negative symptoms
  • Worst prognosis of all types

Post schizophrenic depression

  • Max chance of suicidal attempt

NOTE: prognosis is simple < hebephrenic < paranoid < catatonic in the order- worst, bad, good, best

questions.text: A 45 year old male is brought to casualty after a night party with complaints of epigastric pain, penetrating towards back. Which is the best for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The cardinal symptom of acute pancreatitis is abdominal pain, which is characteristically dull, boring, and steady.         
  • Usually, the pain is sudden in onset and gradually intensifies in severity until reaching a constant ache.
  • The pain radiates directly through the abdomen to the back in approximately one half of cases.
  • Fever (76%) and tachycardia (65%) are common abnormal vital signs; hypotension may be noted
  • Abdominal tenderness, muscular guarding (68%), and distention (65%) are observed in most patients; bowel sounds are often diminished or absent because of gastric and transverse colonic ileus; guarding tends to be more pronounced in the upper abdomen        
  • Lipase has a slightly longer half-life and its abnormalities may support the diagnosis if a delay occurs between the pain episode and the time the patient seeks medical attention.         
  • Elevated lipase levels are more specific to the pancreas than elevated amylase levels. Lipase levels remain high for 12 days. In patients with chronic pancreatitis (usually caused by alcohol abuse and question mentions that the patient is back from a party), lipase levels may be elevated in the presence of a normal serum amylase level.

questions.text: Primigravida with full term, complains of faintness on lying down and she feels well when turns to side or sitting position. This is due to:
questions.solution:
Solutions: -

  • Nausea and dizziness in a pregnant female is due to IVC compression.
  • The gravid uterus compresses the IVC, thus reduces the venous return leading to supine hypotension syndrome.
  • This can be relieved by lying laterally (Left Lateral Position).

Advantages of Left Lateral Position -

  • Improves utero - placental circulation
  • Increase Fetal Oxygen saturation by 10%

questions.text: A woman, gravid 0, para 0,underwent infertility evaluation. The infertility was diagnosed as being secondary to an ovulation because of polycystic ovary syndrome. Which of the following statements is most likely to be true?

choices.text: She has a low body mass index
Androgen production is primarily from adrenals

questions.solution: Gonadotropins are tonically elevated : The underlying mechanism in polycystic ovary syndrome is a tonically elevated luteinizing hormone (LH) level that results in absence of normal menstrual hormone fluctuations. The body mass index is usually high, not low. Although hirsutism is common, virilization is not seen. The androgen production is largely from the ovary, rather than the adrenals.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with three previous abortions develops deep venous thrombosis in her left leg. Which of the following is the probable cause ?
questions.solution: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is liable to cause thrombosis as well as habitual abortions and still birth.

questions.text: A congenitally deaf child on the radiological evaluation of cochlea and brain with MRI has been found to have absent cochlea. What is the best method of hearing rehabilitation in this case?
questions.solution:
• A brain stem implant is placed on the lateral recess of the 4th ventricle near the cochlear nucleus for stimulation.
  • The indications are- NF-2 cases with bilateral acoustic neuromas, congenital absence of VIII nerve, cochlear aplasia (Michel’s).

questions.text: Dharamveer, a 55 years old retired navy personnel presented to emergency 5 days back with complains of chest pain, sweating and breathlessness for 1 hr. ECG showed Anterior wall MI. Angiography showed double vessel disease and Angioplasty was done. He is getting discharged today. All of the following drugs will be mentioned in the discharge card for secondary prevention of MI except?
questions.solution:
SECONDARY PREVENTION OF MI


Responsible for the improvement in the long-term mortality and morbidity rates after STEMI.

  1. Long-term treatment with an antiplatelet agent (usually aspirin) after STEMI is associated with a 25% reduction in the risk of recurrent infarction, stroke, or cardiovascular mortality .An alternative antiplatelet agent that may be used for secondary prevention in patients intolerant of aspirin is clopidogrel (75 mg orally daily).
  2. ACE inhibitors or ARBs and, in appropriate patients, aldosterone antagonists should be used indefinitely by patients with clinically evident heart failure, a moderate decrease in global ejection fraction, or a large regional wall motion abnormality to prevent late ventricular remodeling and recurrent ischemic events.
  3. The chronic routine use of oral beta-adrenoceptor blockers for at least 2 years after STEMI is supported by well-conducted, placebo controlled trials.
  4. warfarin : not used routinely. Most physicians prescribe aspirin routinely for all patients without contraindications and add warfarin for patients at increased risk of embolism .
  5. Side effect: There is an increased risk of bleeding when warfarin is added to dual antiplatelet therapy .However, patients who have had a stent implanted and have an indication for anticoagulation should receive dual antiplatelet therapies in combination with warfarin

PRECAUTIONS

  1. Such patients should also receive a proton pump inhibitor to minimize the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding
  2. Should have regular monitoring.

questions.text: 2 year old child has severe dehydration and unrecordable BP. Attempts to obtain intravenous access fail. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution: intraosseous cannulation is recommended for patients for whom IV access proves difficult or unattainable, even in older children. For children in shock and poor venous access, IO cannulation can be life-saving. Anterior aspect of tibia is the preferred site.

questions.text: A 1 year old child presents with erythematous itchy lesions over the cheeks & extensor of the extremities. Mother is a known case of asthma. Likely diagnosis is ?
questions.solution:
Atopic dermatitis is typically on extensors and on cheeks in early age Major criteria (Hannifin and Rajka) for diagnosis of atopic dermatitis (need 3 or more) are as follows: Pruritus

  • Typical morphology and distribution. Flexural lichenification in adults. Facial and extensor involvement in infants and children. Dermatitis - Chronically or chronically relapsing. Personal or family history of atopy (asthma, allergic rhinitis, atopic dermatitis)

questions.text: A 35 year old nulligravida who desires future fertility, is found during frozen section analysis of a right salpingo-oophorectomy specimen, to have granulosa cell tumour. What is the appropriate surgical management of her condition?

choices.text: RSO, omentectomy, multiple peritoneal biopsy and pelvic pararotic LN dissection
RSO, omentectomy, multiple peritoneal biopsy and pelvic pararotic LN dissection and D & C
TAH with BSO, omentectomy, peritoneal biopsies with pelvic and paraarotic LN dissection

questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Since she is a case of cancer ovary the patient must undergo a complete staging laparotomy, Since she is a nulligravida we will only remove the affected ovary and tube sparing the uterus. The other ovary and the other tube. Omentectomy, peritoneal biopsies and lymph node sampling are steps of staging laparotomy, D&C is added to the procedure because granulosa cell tumour is ostrogen secreting tumour that causes endometrial growth and increases risk of simultaneous endometrial cancer. Granulosa cell tumour is a type of sex cord tumour of the ovary and its tumour marker is INHIBIN .The other sex cord stromal tumour of ovary are - granulosa cell tumours-theca cell - sertoli- leydig tumours-fibroma- fibrosarcoma- steroid cell tumor- sclerosing stromal tumour - signet ring stromal tumour.

questions.text: A 30 year old female gravida 2 presented to antenatal clinic with 2hr OGTT value 200mg/dl. Which among the following is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Start her on insulin therapy 2hr OGTT is used as a screening test for gestational diabetes mellitus and values more than 140 are considered diagnostic. If the patients value is more than or equal to 200 the she has to be directly started on insulin therapy. If the values are more than or equal to 140 then she is initially put only on diabetic diet and reassessed after 2 weeks and then if on diabetic diet her 2hr postprandial levels are more than 120 then she will started on insulin. HbA1C is used for risk assessment of GCA and to know about good control of the patient.

questions.text: What is the ideal period of contraception advisable after treatment with isotretinoin to avoid any teratogenic effects of the drug on the fetus?`
questions.solution: Oral isotretinoin is the drug of choice in stage 4 acne. Side effect of this drug is chelitis due to its sebolytic property and teratogenicity, Period of 3 weeks contraception is advised to avoid teratogenic effects. Wickhams striae are due to underlying hypergranulosis.

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics has the weakest association with the development of Clostridium difficile–associated disease?
questions.solution:
• Clindamycin, ampicillin, and cephalosporins (including ceftriaxone) were the first antibiotics associated with C. difficile–associated disease, and still are.
  • More recently, broad-spectrum fluoroquinolones, including moxifloxacin and ciprofloxacin, have been associated with outbreaks of C. difficile, including outbreaks in some locations of a more virulent strain that has caused severe disease among elderly outpatients.
  • For unclear reasons, β-lactams other than the later generation cephalosporins appear to carry a lesser risk of disease.
  • Penicillin/β-lactamase combination antibiotics appear to have lower risk of C. difficile–associated disease than the other agents mentioned. Cases have even been reported associated with metronidazole and vancomycin administration.

Nevertheless, all patients initiating antibiotics should be warned to seek care if they develop diarrhea that is severe or persists for more than a day, as all antibiotics carry some risk for C. difficile–associated disease.

questions.text: A 26-year-old nulliparous woman is being evaluated for possibility of IUD insertion. Which of the following characteristics is most acceptable for IUD use in women?

choices.text: Enlarged uterus with an irregular cavity

questions.solution: Nulliparity is not a contraindication to IUD insertion. Contraindications include pregnancy, current or recent history of pelvic inflammatory disease, current sexually transmitted disease, current or recent puerperal or post abortion sepsis, purulent cervicitis, undiagnosed abnormal vaginal bleeding, malignancy of the genital tract, known uterine anomalies or fibroids distorting the uterine cavity in a way incompatible with IUD insertion (Note: Small fibroid [3-4 cm] not impinging on the uterine cavity is not a contraindication), or allergy to any component of the IUD or Wilson disease

questions.text: A 40-year-old alcoholic develops cough and fever. Chest x-ray shows an air-fluid level in the superior segment of the right lower lobe. The most likely etiologic agent is
questions.solution:
• Of the organisms listed, only anaerobic infection is likely to cause a necrotizing process.
  • Type III pneumococci have been reported to cause cavitary disease, but this is unusual.
  • The location of the infiltrate suggests aspiration, also making anaerobic infection most likely.
  • The superior segment of the right lower lobe is the one most likely to develop an aspiration pneumonia

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with weakness in her left leg and arm with an obvious facial droop on the left hand side. History taking reveals a sudden onset of loss of function of the left side of her body with no loss of consciousness, tongue-biting or associated incontinence of faeces or urine. Past medical history is remarkable only for four miscarriages and peptic ulcer disease. Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
• Antiphospholipid syndrome is a spectrum of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) often associated with vascular thromboses.
  • The vascular involvement may manifest most strikingly as stroke, myocardial infarction and multi-infarct dementia in a younger population with no obvious identifiable risk factors or more insidiously with migrainous symptoms and recurrent miscarriages.
  • The presence of lupus anticoagulant and anticardiolipin antibodies with the above clinical presentation strongly suggests antiphospholipid syndrome.
  • Reiter’s syndrome typically presents with a triad of urethritis, conjunctivitis and arthritis in a young man associated with sexually transmitted or gastrointestinal infections.
  • Systemic sclerosis is a disorder mainly affecting skin, gastrointestinal tract and respiratory system whilst dermatomyositis, as the name suggests, affects skin and muscle mainly.

Marfan’s syndrome typically affects the aorta and aortic valve, lens of the eye and skeletal system due to mutations in the fibrillin-1 gene.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency room complaining of redness and pain in her right foot up to the level of the midcalf. She reports that her right leg has been swollen for at least 15 years, but her left:- leg has been normal. On physical examination she has a temperature of 39°C (102.2°F). The left leg is normal. The right leg is not tender, but it is swollen from the inguinal ligament down and there is an obvious cellulitis of the right foot. The patient’s underlying problem is ?
questions.solution: This patient is at high risk for developing cellulitis of her right foot because her underlying problem is unilateral primary lymphedema. Hypoplasia of the lymphatic system of the lower extremity accounts for greater than 90% of patients with primary lymphedema. If edema is present at birth it is referred to as congenital; if it starts early in life (as in this woman) it is called praecox; and if it appears after age 35 it is tarda. The inadequacy of the lymphatic system accounts for the repeated episodes of cellulitis that these patients experience. Swelling is not seen with acute arterial insufficiency or with popliteal entrapment syndrome. Deep venous thrombophlebitis will result in tenderness and is generally not a predisposing factor for cellulitis of the foot.

questions.text: A 50 year old woman with right sided pleural effusion undergoes exploratory laprotomy for a pelvic mass and raised CA125. On exploration there are macroscopic peritoneal deposits and deposits on liver capsule cytologic examination of pleural fluid shows malignant cells. What FIGO stage is she?
questions.solution: The staging for cervical cancer is surgical and the procedure is called staging laparotomy In general the overall survival rate of all types of ovarian cancer is 45% For epithelial ovarian cancer stage wise survival is STAGE 1A and 18 IS 92% STAGE 1C 85% STAGE 2 70% SATGE 3 39% STAGE 4 17% Cancer with macroscopic deposits on the peritoneum and involvement of capsule of liver and spleen can be either stage 3b or 3c Pleural effusion with demonstration of malignant cells will change the stage of the cancer to 4A The age and raised CA125 depicts that this is most likely a case of epithelial ovarian cancer and advanced stage She will undergo staging laparotomy with TAH and BSO The tumour marker for serous epithelial ovarian cancer is CA125 while that for mucinous is CEA.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with pituitary tumor, prolactinoma encircling the carotid artery. Which of the following is the best line of management?
questions.solution:
• Most of the tumors in sellar region are benign pituitary adenomas, but also include craniopharyngiomas, meningiomas, aneurysm and Rathke cleft cyst.
  • Pituitary microadenomas are less than 1 cm in size and macroadenoma are more than 1 cm.
  • Microadenomas present with endocrine effects, whereas macroadenoma present with visual field defects.
  • Majority of the adenomas are prolactinomas (30%), 20% are non-functioning, 15% secrete GH and 10% secrete ACTH.
  • Baseline assessment of serum prolaction, FSH and LH, TFT and fasting serum GH and cortisol is necessary.
  • Prolactinomas are initially managed with dopamine agonists like bromocriptine and carbergoline.
  • Compression of the chiasm with evidence of visual compromise , encasement of nearby cavernous sinus or carotid arteries are the indication of surgical intervention.
  • Surgical resection is usually performed through transsphenoidal approach using a microscope or endoscope inserted through nose.
  • Postoperative complications inside CSF leak, pituitary insufficiency and SIADH.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain. She is found to have an enlarged spleen with pain localised to the left upper quadrant. Blood tests reveal a haemoglobin level of 9.8 g/dL with an mean cell volume (MCV) of 92fL. WBC was 26 X 109 and platelet count was 135 X 109. Which of the following chromosomal translocations is most likely to be found in sufferers of this condition?
questions.solution:
• This question is difficult only because it requires a knowledge of the genetic translocation associated with the more familiar bcr–abl fusion gene (Philadelphia chromosome). Genetic translocations are responsible for a large number of genetic predispositions to cancer.
  • Another commonly seen translocation associated with cancer is the t(8;14) c-myc activation leading to an increased risk of developing Burkitt’s lymphoma. A handy way to remember the chromosomes involved in the Philadelphia chromosome is as follows.
  • Philadelphia chromosome – the ‘P’ of Philadelphia is located at the 9th position and there are 22 letters in the two words put together (hence 9;22).
  • The t(11;22) translocation is commonly associated with a rare bone tumour seen almost exclusively in children and young adults. It is a highly malignant tumour that has a high mortality rate in those who are afflicted.
  • Robertsonian translocations are a type of genetic transfer of chromosomal material that occurs in association with a number of disorders, most commonly with Down syndrome.
  • Robertsonian translocations can be balanced, in which case there is no loss or addition of chromosomal material and the person carrying that karyotype will be a carrier of Down syndrome and not be afflicted, or unbalanced, resulting in trisomy or monosomy (the latter of which is non-viable).

Down syndrome involves trisomy of chromosome 21 and may involve a combination of nearby chromosomes. The translocation t(14;21) is relatively frequently identified as the cause of this disease.

questions.text: One of the following statements is incorrect about IPSID (immune-proliferative small intestinal disease) ?

choices.text: Most common in 5th decade of life
In premalignant stage, tetracycline can cure the disease

questions.solution:
• Patients with IPSID present with chronic diarrhea and malabsorption in the second and third decades of life.
  • Abdominal pain is usually a significant complaint, accompanied by weight loss and nutritional deficiencies.
  • On physical examination, clubbing of the fingers may be noted and abdominal masses may be palpated.
  • The disease is caused by a clonal proliferation of cells that produce an abnormal alpha heavy chain immunoglobulin, and can be diagnosed by immunoassay for the alpha heavy chain in the serum. It is suggested that the clonal expansion is driven by an infectious antigen, in a way similar to the link between Hp and mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma of the stomach. Indeed, Campylobacter jejuni infection has been causally associated with IPSID.
  • Mucosal biopsy of the small intestine reveals a dense cellular lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate in the lamina propria that results in crypt effacement. The disease progresses over several years from a relatively benign infiltration of the entire small intestinal mucosa (stage A) to the development of lymphoplasmacytic and immunoblastic lymphoma (stage C).
  • The disease is staged as other lymphomas by bone marrow examination, by looking for evidence of disease on either side of the diaphragm, and by CT of the abdomen.
  • In patients with stage a disease diagnosed by mucosal biopsy, it is advisable to perform laparoscopy or laparotomy with full-thickness biopsy of the intestine to exclude transmural lymphoma before commencing antibiotic therapy.

Areas of bulky tumor also are resected before chemotherapy and biopsy of enlarged mesenteric nodes is performed.

questions.text: A 22 year old primigravida presents with 12 weeks of amenorrhoea and heavy vaginal bleeding. Her HCG is 15000 miu/ml. Tissue is seen in the cervical canal. What is your diagnosis and management plan include which of the following ?

choices.text: Complete abortion, plan subsequent hcg test in 48 hrs
Ectopia tubal pregnancy, plan laparoscopic resection
Incomplete abortion, plan dilation and evacuation

questions.solution: Heavy bleeding with open os and products of conception visible through the cervical os, she is a case of incomplete abortion and along with symptomatic management the treatment of choice is evacuation of the products of conception In complete abortion the bleeding subsides and the os is closed In threatened abortion the bleeding is minimum and the os is open and on ultrasound examination fetal cardiac activity is present

questions.text: A neonate having congenital diaphragmatic hernia is brought with respiratory distress to emergency on 2nd day of life. On intubating, the apex beat shifted to right and distress worsened. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution: In a child with CDH. bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated. If a child with CDH is asymptomatic first clinical intervention is to insert a nasogastric tube and keep it open. If however he presents in distress (as in this question), the first clinical intervention is to intubate the child and start PPV by ET tube. Now if distress worsens and apex beat shifts to right, it suggests esophageal intubation, which can be confirmed by capnography for ETCO2 measurement. If capnography not available, remove tube and reattempt intubation. There is no role of emergency surgery in COH.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents to clinic with severe pain in the left femur. The pain is relieved by aspirin. X-ray was advised and on plain film, a 0.5-cm lucent lesion, which is surrounded by marked reactive sclerosis, is seen. Diagnosis is ?
questions.solution:
• An osteoid osteoma typically presents with severe pain that is characteristically relieved by aspirin.
  • On radiograph, the lesion appears as a small lucency within the bone that is surrounded by reactive sclerosis.
  • These lesions gradually regress over 5–10 years, but most are excised to relieve symptoms. Surgical extirpation is usually curative

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman is recovering from a major pelvic cancer operation and develops severe abdominal pain and sepsis. Following a positive HIDA scan, laparotomy is performed. The gall-bladder is severely inflamed and removed. There is no evidence of gallbladder stones (acalculous cholecystitis). Cholecystectomy is performed. Which is true of acalculous cholecystitis?

choices.text: It is usually associated with stones in the CBD.
It occurs in 10–20% of cases of cholecystitis.
It has a more favorable prognosis than calculous cholecystitis.
It is increased in frequency after trauma or operation.

questions.solution: Acute acalculous cholecystitis is most commonly encountered in critically ill patients after trauma, other unrelated surgical operations, burns, sepsis, and multiorgan failure. The HIDA scan fails to visualize the gallbladder, and a sonogram may show a distended gall-bladder with wall thickening and perichole-cystic fluid. Acalculous cholecystitis carries a mortality rate of 10–30%. Delay in diagnosis and hence treatment is accompanied by severe complications, such as gangrene and perforation of the gallbladder in a patient who usually has other debilitating illnesses

questions.text: A patient presents to you with mucopurulent urethral discharge. He reports having an unprotected sexual exposure 10 days back. A few days later, he complaints of heel pain and swelling of the knee joint. He also reports that his eyes are watering and are red. His skin manifestation could be ?

choices.text: Whitish discoloration and fissuring of the prepuce

questions.solution: Mucopurulent urethral discharge is due to chlamydia trachomatis (STD). Heel pain (enthesitis) and swelling of the knee joint (arthritis) Eye watering with redness is due to eye involvement in reactive arthritis. Plantar hyperkeratosis with oozing is due to keratoderma blenorrhagica. Plaques on extensor surfaces would be in psoriasis. Whitish discoloration and fissuring of the prepuce is candidal balano-posthitis

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman presents with intense pruritus of the vulva. On examination, the vaginal introitus is stenotic. Study the given image, which of the following treatments is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
The lesion described is that of lichen sclerosis.

Lichen Sclerosis

  • Small bluish-white papules that coalesce into white papules
  • Pruritus(‘Itch-scratch’ cycle), dyspareunia, dysuria
  • Histology-Moderate hyperkeratosis with epithelial thinning, acanthosis, basement membrane thickening. Loss of rete hyalinization in dermis
  • Ca vulva of Keratinizing types which is Unifocal and seen in older patients, is found in areas adjacent to lichen sclerosis and squamous hyperplasia.
  • Biopsy for Diagnosis

The key finding is the atrophic skin description. The treatment of choice is topical clobetasol 5-Fluorouracil is used for neoplasias. Miconazole is an antifungal agent

questions.text: A 30 year old farmer is admitted with fever, myalgias and cough. He has conjunctival suffusion and headache; his liver & spleen are palpable. BP=80/60. Blood culture is negative. TLC=14,000. Platelet count is 1 lakh. Liver enzymes are elevated. These are pictures related to his illness. Which of the following statements is TRUE?

Image B shows a maculopapular rash which confirms the diagnosis of Lyme disease in this patient
Image A shows an eschar which confirms the diagnosis of anthrax in this patient
Infected chiggers inoculate organisms into the skin

Scrub typhus
